titlePage.titlePart: THE TRAGEDIE OF Anthonie, and Cleopatra.

div2.head: Actus Primus. Scoena Prima.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: Nay, but this dotage of our Generals
Overflows the measure: those his goodly eyes
That over the Files and Musters of the War,
Have glowed like plated Mars:
Now bend, now turn
The Office and Devotion of their view
Upon: a Tawny Front. His Captains heart,
Which in the scuffles of great Fights hath burst
The Buckles on his breast, reneges all temper,
And is become the Bellows and the Fan
To cool a Gypsies Lust.
sp.stage:
Flourish. Enter Anthony, Cleopatra, her Ladies, the
Traine, with Eunuchs fanning her.
sp.l: Look where they come:
Take but good note, and you shall see in him
(The triple Pillar of the world) transformed
Into a Strumpets Fool. Behold and see.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: If it be Love indeed, tell me how much.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There is beggary in the love that can be reckoned

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I will set a bourne how far to be beloved.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then must thou needs find out new Heaven, new Earth.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: News (my good Lord) from Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Grates me, the sum.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Nay hear them Anthony.
Fuluia perchance is angry: Or who knows,
If the scarce-bearded Cæsar have not sent
His powerful Mandate to you. Do this, or this;
Take in that Kingdom, and Enfranchise that:
Perform it, or else we damn thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How, my Love?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Perchance? Nay, and most like::
You must not stay here longer, your dismission
Is come from Cæsar, therefore hear it Anthony,
Where is Fuluias Process? (Cæsars I would say) both?
Call in the Messengers: As I am Egypts Queen,
Thou blushest Anthony, and that blood of thine
Is Cæsars homager: else so thy cheek pays shame,
When shrill-tongued Fuluia scolds. The Messengers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let Rome in Tyber melt, and the wide Arch
Of the ranged Empire fall: Here is my space,
Kingdoms are clay: Our dungy earth alike
Feeds Beast as Man; the Nobleness of life
Is to do thus: when such a mutual pair,
And such a twain can do it, in which I bind
On: pain of punishment, the world to weet
We stand up: Peerless.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Excellent falsehood:
Why did he marry Fuluia, and not love her?
I will seem the Fool I am not. Anthony will be himself.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But stirred by Cleopatra.
Now for the love of Love, and her soft hours,
Let us not confound the time with Conference harsh;
There is not a minute of our lives should stretch
Without some pleasure now. What sport tonight?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Hear the Ambassadors.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fie wrangling Queen:
Whom everything becomes, to chide, to laugh,
To weep: who every passion fully strives
To make itself (in Thee)fair, and admired.
No Messenger but thine, and all alone, tonight
We will wander through the streets, and note
The qualities of people. Come my Queen,
Last night you did desire it. Speak not to us.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is Cæsar with Anthonius prized so slight?

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: Sir, sometimes when he is not Anthony,
He comes too short of that great Property
Which still should go with Anthony.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I am full sorry, that he approves the common Liar, who thus speaks of him at Rome; but I will hope of better deeds tomorrow. Rest you happy.

div2.stage:
Enter Enobarbus, Lamprius, a Southsayer, Rannius, Lucillius,
Charmian, Iras, Mardian the Eunuch,
and Alexas.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything Alexas,
almost most absolute Alexas, where is the Soothsayer
that you praised so to the Queen? O that I knew this
Husband, which you say, must change his Horns with
Garlands.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Soothsayer.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: Your will?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Is this the Man? Is it you sir that know things?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
In Natures infinite book of Secrecy, a little I
can read.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Show him your hand.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Bring in the Banquet quickly: Wine enough,
Cleopatra's health to drink.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Good sir, give me good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: I make not, but foresee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Pray then, foresee me one.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: You shall be yet far fairer than you are.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He means in flesh.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: No, you shall paint when you are old.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Wrinkles forbid.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Vex not his prescience, be attentive.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Hush.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: You shall be more beloving, than beloved.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I had rather heat my Liver with drinking.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Nay, hear him.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Good now some excellent Fortune: Let me
be married to three Kings in a forenoon, and Widow
them all: Let me have a Child at fifty, to whom Herode
of Jewry may do Homage. Find me to marry me with
Octauius Cæsar, and companion me with
my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: You shall outlive the Lady whom you serve.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: O excellent, I love long life better than Figs.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
You have seen and proved a fairer former fortune,
than that which is to approach.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Then belike my Children shall have no names:
Prithee how many Boys and Wenches must I have.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
If every of your wishes had a womb, and fore-tell
every wish, a Million.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Out Fool, I forgive thee for a Witch.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
You think none but your sheets are privy to
your wishes.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nay come, tell Iras hers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: We will know all our Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Mine, and most of our Fortunes tonight, shall
be drunk to bed.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: There is a Palm presages Chastity, if nothing else.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Even as the over-flowing" Nylus presageth Famine.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: Go you wild Bedfellow, you cannot Soothsay.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Nay, if an oily Palm be not a fruitful Prognostication,
I cannot scratch mine ear. Prithee tell her
but a work day Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: Your Fortunes are alike.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: But how, but how, give me particulars.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p: I have said.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: Am I not an inch of Fortune better than she?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better
than I: where would you choose it.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p: Not in my Husbands nose.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Our worser thoughts Heavens mend.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Come, his Fortune, his Fortune. O let him
marry a woman that cannot go, sweet Isis, I beseech thee,
and let her die too, and give him a worse, and let worse
follow worse, till the worst of all follow him laughing to:
his grave, fifty-fold a Cuckold. Good Isis hear me this
Prayer, though thou deny me a matter of more weight:
good Isis I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.p:
Amen, dear Goddess, hear that prayer of the
people. For:, as it is a heart-breaking to see a handsome
man loose-Wived, so it is a deadly sorrow, to behold a
foul Knave uncuckolded: Therefore dear Isis keep decorum,
and Fortune him accordingly.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Lo now, if it lay in their hands to make me a
Cuckold, they would make themselves Whores, but
they would do it.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Hush, here comes Anthony.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Not he, the Queen.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Save you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: No Lady.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Was he not here?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He was disposed to mirth, but on the sudden
A Roman thought hath struck him.
Enobarbus?

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Seek him, and bring him hither: where is Alexias?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Here at your service.
My Lord approaches.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: We will not look upon: him:
Go with us.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: Fuluia thy Wife,
First came into the Field.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Against my Brother Lucius?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: Aye: but soon that War had end,
And the times state
Made friends of them, jointing their force against Cæsar,
Whose better issue in the war from Italy,
Upon: the first encounter drove them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, what worst.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: The Nature of bad news infects the Teller.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When it concerns the Fool or Coward: On:.
Things that are past, are done, with me. It is thus,
Who tells me true, though in his Tale lie death,
I hear him as he flattered.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Labienus (this is stiff-news)
Hath with his Parthian Force
Extended Asia: from Euphrates his conquering
Banner shook, from Syria to Lydia,
And to Ionia, whilst -;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Anthony thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: O my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speak to me home,
Mince not the general tongue, name
Cleopatra as she is called in Rome:

Rail thou in Fuluia's phrase, and taunt my
faults
With such full License, as both Truth and Malice
Have power to utter. O then we bring forth weeds,
When our quick winds lie still, and our ills told us
Is as our earing: fare thee well awhile.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: At your Noble pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: From Scicion how the news? Speak there.

sp.speaker: 1.Mes.
sp.l: The man from Scicion,
Is there such an one?

sp.speaker: 2.Mes.
sp.l: He stays upon: your will:.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let him appear:
These strong Egyptian Fetters I must break,
Or lose myself in dotage.
sp.stage: Enter another Messenger with a Letter.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: 3.Mes.
sp.l: Fuluia thy wife is dead.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where died she.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: In Scicion, her length of sickness,
With what else more serious,
Importeth thee to know, this bears.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Forbear me
There is a great Spirit gone, thus did I desire it:
What our contempts doth often hurl from us,
We wish it ours again. The present pleasure,
By revolution lowering, does become
The opposite of itself: she is good being gone,
The hand could pluck her back, that should her on:.
I must from this enchanting Queen break off,
Ten thousand harms, more than the ills I know
My idleness doth hatch.
How now Enobarbus.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: What is your pleasure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I must with haste from hence.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Why then we kill all our Women. We see how
mortal an unkindness is to them, if they suffer our departure
death is the word.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Under a compelling an occasion, let women die.
It were pity to cast them away for nothing, though between
them and a great cause, they should be esteemed
nothing. Cleopatra catching but the least noise of this,
dies instantly: I have seen her die twenty times upon
far poorer moment: I do think there is mettle in death,
which commits some loving act upon: her, she hath such
a celerity in dying.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: She is cunning past man's thought.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Alack Sir no, her passions are made of nothing
but the finest part of pure Love. We cannot call her winds
and waters, sighs and tears: They are greater storms
and Tempests than Almanacs can report. This cannot
be cunning in her: if it be, she makes a shower of Rain
as well as Ioue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Would I had never seen her.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
O sir, you had then left unseen a wonderful
piece of work, which not to have been blessed withal,
would have discredited your Travail.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fuluia is dead.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fuluia is dead.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Fuluia?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dead.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Why sir, give the Gods a thankful Sacrifice:
when it pleaseth their Deities to take the wife of a man
from him, it shows to man the Tailors of the earth: comforting
therein, that when old Robes are worn out,
there are members to make new. If there were no more
Women but Fuluia, then had you indeed a cut, and the
case to be lamented: This grief is crowned with Consolation,
your old Smock brings forth a new Petticoat,
and indeed the tears live in an Onion, that should water
this sorrow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The business she hath broached in the State,
Cannot endure my absence.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
And the business you have broached here cannot
be without you, especially that of Cleopatra's, which
wholly depends on your abode.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more light Answers
Let our Officers
Have notice what we purpose. I shall break
The cause of our Expedience to the Queen,
And get her love to part. For not alone
The death of Fuluia, with more urgent touches
Do strongly speak to us: but the Letters too
Of many our contriving Friends in Rome,
Petition us at home. Sextus Pompeius
Have given the dare to Cæsar, and commands
The Empire of the Sea. Our slippery people,
Whose Love is never linked to the deserver,
Till his deserts are past, begin to throw
Pompey the great, and all his Dignities
Upon: his Son, who high in Name and Power,
Higher than both in Blood and Life, stands up:
For the main Soldier. Whose quality going on:,
The sides of the world may danger. Much is breeding,
Which like the Coursers heir, hath yet but life,
And not a Serpents poison. Say our pleasure,
To such whose places under us, require
Our quick remove from hence.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: I shall do it.

div2.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Alexas, and Iras.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I did not see him since.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: See where he is,
Who is with him, what he does:
I did not send you. If you find him sad,
Say I am dancing: if in Mirth, report
That I am sudden sick. Quick, and return.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Madam, methinks if you did love him dearly,
You do not hold the method, to enforce
The like from him.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What should I do, I do not?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: In each thing give him way, cross him in nothing.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Thou teachest like a fool: the way to lose him.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Tempt him not so too far. I wish forbear,
In time we hate that which we often fear.
But here comes Anthony.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am sick, and sullen.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Help me away dear Charmian, I shall fall,
It cannot be thus long, the sides of Nature
Will not sustain it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now my dearest Queen.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Pray you stand farther from me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I know by that same eye there is some good news.
What says the married woman you may go?
Would she had never given you leave to come.
Let her not say it is I that keep you here,
I have no power upon: you: Hers you are.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Gods best know.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O never was there Queen
So mightily betrayed: yet at the first
I saw the Treasons planted.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Why should I think you can be mine, and true,
(Though you in swearing shake the Throned Gods)
Who have been false to Fuluia?
Riotous madness,
To be entangled with those mouth-made vows,
Which break themselves in swearing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Most sweet Queen.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Nay pray you seek no colour for your going,
But bid farewell, and go:
When you sued staying,
Then was the time for words: No going then,
Eternity was in our Lips, and Eyes,
Bliss in our brows bent: none our parts so poor,
But was a race of Heaven. They are so still,
Or thou the greatest Soldier of the world,
Art turned the greatest Liar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now Lady?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I would I had thy inches, thou shouldst know
There were a heart in Egypt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hear me Queen:
The strong necessity of Time, commands
Our Services awhile: but my full heart
Remains in use with you. Our Italy,
Shines over with civil Swords; Sextus Pompeius
Makes his approaches to the Port of Rome,
Equality of two Domestic powers,
Breed scrupulous faction: The hated grown to strength
Are newly grown to Love: The condemned Pompey,
Rich in his Fathers Honour, creeps apace
Into the hearts of such, as have not thrived
Upon: the present state, whose Numbers threaten,
And quietness grown sick of rest, would purge
By any desperate change: My more particular,
And that which most with you should safe my going,
Is Fuluias death.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Though age from folly could not give me freedom
It does from childishness. Can Fuluia die?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is dead my Queen.
Look here, and at thy Sovereign leisure read
The Garboils she awaked: at the last, best,
See when, and where she died.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O most false Love!
Where be the Sacred Violas thou shouldst fill
With sorrowful water? Now I see, I see,
In Fuluias death, how mine received shall be.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Quarrel no more, but be prepared to know
The purposes I bear: which are, or cease,
As you shall give the advice . By the fire
That quickens Nylus slime, I go from hence
Thy Soldier, Servant, making Peace or War,
As thou affects.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Cut my Lace, Charmian come,
But let it be, I am quickly ill, and well,
So Anthony loves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My precious Queen forbear,
And give true evidence to his Love, which stands
An honourable Trial.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: So Fuluia told me.
I prithee turn aside, and weep for her,
Then bid adieu to me, and say the tears
Belong to Egypt. Good now, play one Scene
Of excellent dissembling, and let it look
Like perfect Honour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You will: heat my blood no more?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: You can do better yet: but this is meetly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now by Sword.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: And Target. Still he mends.
But this is not the best. Look prithee Charmian,
How this Herculean Roman does become
The carriage of his chafe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will leave you Lady.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Courteous Lord, one word:
Sir, you and I must part, but that is not it:
Sir, you and I have loved, but there is not it:
That you know well, something it is I would:
O, my Oblivion is a very Anthony,
And I am all forgotten.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But that your Royalty
Holds Idleness your subject, I should take you
For Idleness itself.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: It is sweating Labour,
To bear such Idleness so near the heart
As Cleopatra this. But Sir, forgive me,
Since my becomings kill me, when they do not
Eye well to you. Your Honour calls you hence,
Therefore be deaf to my unpitied Folly,
And all the Gods go with you. Upon: your Sword
Sit Laurel victory, and smooth success
Be strewed before your feet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let us go.
Come: Our separation so abides and flies,
That thou residing here, goes yet with me;
And I hence fleeting, here remain with thee.
Away.

div2.stage:
Enter Octauius reading a Letter, Lepidus,
and their Traine.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: You may see Lepidus, and henceforth know,
It is not Cæsars
Natural vice, to hate
One great Competitor. From Alexandria
This is the news: He fishes, drinks, and wastes
The Lamps of night in revel: Is not more man-like
Than Cleopatra: nor the Queen of Ptolomy
More Womanly than he. Hardly gave audience
Or vouchsafe to think he had Partners. You
Shall find there a man, who is the abstracts of all faults,
That all men follow.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: I must not think
There are, evils enough to darken all his goodness:
His faults in him, seem as the Spots of Heaven,
More fiery by nights Blackness; Hereditary,
Rather than purchased: what he cannot change,
Than what he chooses.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: You are too indulgent. Let us grant it is not
Amiss to tumble on the bed of Ptolomy,
To give a Kingdom for a Mirth, to sit
And keep the turn of Tippling with a Slave,
To reel the streets at noon, and stand the Buffet
With knaves that smells of sweat: Say this becomes him
(As his composure must be rare indeed,
Whom these things cannot blemish) yet must Anthony
No way excuse his foils, when we do bear
So great weight in his lightness. If he filled
His vacancy with his Voluptuousness,
Full surfeits, and the dryness of his bones,
Call on him for it. But to confound such time,
That drums him from his sport, and speaks as loud
As his own State, and ours, it is to be chid:
As we rate Boys, who being mature in knowledge,
Pawn their experience to their present pleasure,
And so rebel to judgment.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Here is more news.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Thy biddings have been done, and every hour
Most Noble Cæsar, shalt thou have report
How it is abroad. Pompey is strong at Sea,
And it appears, he is beloved of those
That only have feared Cæsar: to the Ports
The discontents repair, and men's reports
Give him much wronged.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: I should have known no less,
It hath been taught us from the primal state
That he which is was wished, until he were:
And the ebbed man,
Never loved, till never worth love,
Comes feared, by being lacked. This common body,
Like to a Vagabond Flag upon: the Stream,
Goes to, and back, lacking the varying tide
To rot itself with motion.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Cæsar I bring thee word,
Menacrates and Menas famous Pirates
Makes the Sea serve them, which they ear and wound
With keels of every kind. Many hot inroads
They make in Italy, the Borders Maritime
Lack blood to think of it, and flush youth revolt,
No Vessel can peep forth: but it is as soon
Taken as seen: for Pompeyes name strikes more
Than could his War resisted.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Anthony,
Leave thy lascivious Vassals. When thou once
Was beaten from Medena, where thou slewest
Hirsius, and Pansa Consuls, at thy heel
Did Famine follow, whom thou foughtest against,
(Though daintily brought up:) with patience more
Than Savages could suffer. Thou didst drink
The stale of Horses, and the gilded Puddle
Which Beasts would cough at. Thy palate then did deign
The roughest Berry, on the rudest Hedge.
Yea, like the Stag, when Snow the Pasture sheets,
The barks of Trees thou browsed. On the Alps,
It is reported thou didst eat strange flesh,
Which some did die to look on:: And all this
(It wounds thine Honour that I speak it now)
Was born so like a Soldier, that thy cheek
So much as lanked not.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: It is pity of him.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Let his shames quickly
Drive him to Rome, it is time we twain
Did show ourselves in the Field, and to that end
Assemble me immediate counsel, Pompey
Thrives in our Idleness.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Tomorrow Cæsar,
I shall be furnished to inform you rightly
Both what by Sea and Land I can be able
To front this present time.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Till which encounter, it is my business too. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Farewell my Lord, what you shall know mean time
Of stirs abroad, I shall beseech you Sir
To let me be partaker.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Doubt not sir, I knew it for my Bond.

div2.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Mardian.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Charmian.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, give me to drink Mandragora.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Why Madam?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: That I might sleep out this great gap of time:
My Anthony is away.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You think of him too much.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O it is Treason.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Madam, I trust not so:.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Thou, Eunuch Mardian?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What is your Highness pleasure?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Not now to hear thee sing. I take no pleasure
In ought an Eunuch has: It is well for thee,
That being unseminared, thy freer thoughts
May not fly forth of Egypt. Hast thou Affections?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes gracious Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not in deed Madam, for I can do nothing
But what in deed is honest to be done:
Yet have I fierce Affections, and think
What Venus did with Mars.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O Charmion:
Where thinkst thou he is now? Stands he, or sits he?
Or does he walk? Or is he on his Horse?
O happy horse to bear the weight of Anthony!
Do bravely Horse, for wotest thou whom thou movest,
The demi Atlas of this Earth, the Arm
And Burganet of men. He is speaking now,
Or murmuring, where is my Serpent of old Nyle,
(For so he calls me:) Now I feed myself
With most delicious poison. Think on me
That am with Phoebus amorous pinches black,
And wrinkled deep in time. Broad-fronted Cæsar,
When thou wast here above the ground, I was
A morsel for a Monarch: and great Pompey
Would stand and make his eyes grow in my brow,
There would he anchor his Aspect, and die
With looking on his life.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Sovereign of Egypt, hail.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: How much unlike art thou Marke Anthony?
Yet coming from him, that great Medicine hath
With his Tinct gilded thee.
How goes it with my brave Marke Anthonie?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Last thing he did (dear Queen)
He kissed the last of many doubled kisses
This Orient Pearl. His speech sticks in my heart.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Mine ear must pluck it thence.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Good Friend, quoth he:
Say the firm Roman to great Egypt sends
This treasure of an Oyster: at whose foot
To mend the petty present, I will piece
Her opulent Throne, with Kingdoms. All the East,
(Say thou) shall call her Mistress. So he nodded,
And soberly did mount an Arm-gaunt Steed,
Who neighed so high, that what I would have spoke,
Was beastly dumb by him.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What was he sad, or merry?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Like to the time of the yeare, between the extremes
Of hot and cold, he was nor sad nor merry.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O well divided disposition: Note him,
Note him good Charmian, it is the man; but note him.
He was not sad, for he would shine on those
That make their looks by his. He was not merry,
Which seemed to tell them, his remembrance lay
In Egypt with his joy, but between both.
O heavenly mingle! Beest thou sad, or merry,
The violence of either thee becomes,
So does it no man's else. Metest thou my Posts?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Aye Madam, twenty several Messengers.
Why do you send so thick?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Who is born that day, when I forget to send
to Anthonie, shall die a Beggar. Ink and paper Char-mian.
Welcome my good Alexas. Did I Charmian, ever
love Cæsar so:?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Be choked with such another Emphasis,
Say the brave Anthony.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: The valiant Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: By Isis, I will give thee bloody teeth,
If thou with Cæsar Paragon again:
My man of men.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: By your most gracious pardon,
I sing but after you.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: My Salad days,
When I was green in judgment, cold in blood,
To say, as I said then. But come, away,

Get me Ink and Paper,
he shall have every day a several greeting, or I will unpeople
Egypt.

div2.stage:
Enter Pompey, Menecrates, and Menas, in
warlike manner.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: If the great Gods be just, they shall assist
The deeds of justest men.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.p:
Know worthy Pompey, that what they do delay,
they not deny.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Whiles we are suitors to their Throne, decays
the thing we sue for:.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: We ignorant of ourselves,
Beg often our own harms, which the wise Powers
Deny us for our good: so find we profit
By loosing of our Prayers.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I shall do well:
The people love me, and the Sea is mine;
My powers are Crescent, and my Auguring hope
Says it will come to the full. Marke Anthony
In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make
No wars without doors. Cæsar gets money where
He looses hearts: Lepidus flatters both,
Of both is flattered: but he neither loves,
Nor either cares for him.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Cæsar and Lepidus are in the field,
A mighty strength they carry.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Where have you this? It is false.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: From Siluius, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: He dreams: I know they are in Rome together
Looking for Anthony: but all the charms of Love,
Salt Cleopatra soften thy wand lip,
Let Witchcraft join with Beauty, Lust with both,
Tie up: the Libertine in a field of Feasts,
Keep his Brain fuming. Epicurean Cooks,
Sharpen with cloyless sauce his Appetite,
That sleep and feeding may prorogue his Honour,
Even till a Lethied dullness -;
How now Varrius?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: This is most certain, that I shall deliver:
Marke Anthony is every hour in Rome
Expected. Since he went from Egypt, it is
A space for farther Travail.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I could have given less matter
A better ear. Menas, I did not think
This amorous Surfeiter would have donned his Helm
For such a petty War: His Soldiership
Is twice the other twain: But let us rear
The higher our Opinion, that our stirring
Can from the lap of Egypts Widow, pluck
The near Lust-wearied Anthony

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: I cannot hope,
Cæsar and Anthony shall well greet together;
His Wife that is dead, did trespasses to Cæsar,
His Brother waned upon: him, although I think
Not moved by Anthony.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I know not Menas,
How lesser Enmities may give way to greater,
Were it not that we stand up: against them all:
It were pregnant they should square between themselves,
For they have entertained cause enough
To draw their swords: but how the fear of us
May Cement their divisions, and bind up:
The petty difference, we yet not know:
Be it as our Gods will have it; it only stands
Our lives upon:, to use our strongest hands
Come Menas.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Good Enobarbus, it is a worthy deed,
And shall become you well, to entreat your Captain
To soft and gentle speech.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: I shall entreat him
To answer like himself: if Cæsar move him,
Let Anthony look over Cæsars head,
And speak as loud as Mars. By Iupiter,
Were I the wearer of Anthonio's Beard,
I would not shaue it today.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: It is not a time for private stomaching.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Every time serves for the matter that is then
born in it.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: But small to greater matters must give way.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Not if the small come first.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Your sp is passion: but pray you stir
No Embers up:. Here comes the Noble Anthony.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: And yonder Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If we compose well here, to Parthia:
Hark Ventidius.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: I do not know Mecenas, ask Agrippa .

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Noble Friends:
That which combined us was most great, and let not
A leaner action rend us. What is amiss,
May it be gently heard. When we debate
Our trivial difference loud, we do commit
Murther in healing wounds. Then Noble Partners,
The rather for I earnestly beseech,
Touch you the sourest points with sweetest terms,
Nor curstness grow to the matter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is spoken well:
Were we before our Armies, and to fight,
I should do thus.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Welcome to Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Sit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sit sir.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I learn, you take things ill, which are not so::
Or being, concern you not.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: I must be laughed at, if or for nothing, or a little, I
Should say myself offended, and with you
Chiefly in the world. More laughed at, that I should
Once name you derogately: when to sound your name
It not concerned me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My being in Egypt Cæsar, what was it to you?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: No more than my residing here at Rome
Might be to you in Egypt: yet if you there
Did practise on my State, your being in Egypt
Might be my question.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How intend you, practised?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: You may be pleased to catch at mine intent,
By what did here befall me. Your Wife and Brother
Made wars upon: me, and their contestation
Was Theme for you, you were the word of war.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You do mistake your business, my Brother never
Did urge me in his Act: I did inquire it.
And have my Learning from some true reports
That drew their swords with you, did he not rather
Discredit my authority with yours,
And make the wars alike against my stomach,
Having alike your cause. Of this, my Letters
Before did satisfy you. If you will: patch a quarrel,
As matter whole you have to make it with,
It must not be with this.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: You praise yourself, by laying defects of judgment
to me: but you patched up: your excuses.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Not so:, not so::
I know you could not lack, I am certain of it,
Very necessity of this thought, that I
Your Partner in the cause against which he fought,
Could not with graceful eyes attend those Wars
Which fronted mine own peace. As for my wife,
I would you had her spirit, in such another,
The third of the world is yours, which with a Snaffle,
You may pace easy, but not such a wife.

sp.speaker: Enobar.
sp.p:
Would we had all such wives, that the men
might go to Wars with the women.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: So much uncurbable, her Garboils (Cæsar)
Made out of her impatience: which not wanted
Shrewdness of policy too: I grieving grant,
Did you too much disquiet, for that you must,
But say I could not help it.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: I wrote to you, when rioting in Alexandria you
Did pocket up: my Letters: and with taunts
Did gibe my Missive out of audience.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, he fell upon: me, ere admitted, then:
Three Kings I had newly feasted, and did want
Of what I was in the morning: but next day
I told him of myself, which was as much
As to have asked him pardon. Let this Fellow
Be nothing of our strife: if we contend
Out of our question wipe him.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
You have broken the Article of your oath,
which you shall never have tongue to charge me with.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Soft Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No Lepidus, let him speak,
The Honour is Sacred which he talks of now,
Supposing that I lacked it: but on Cæsar,
The Article of my oath.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
To lend me Arms, and aid when I required
them, the which you both denied.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Neglected rather:
And then when poisoned hours had bound me up:
From mine own knowledge, as nearly as I may,
I will play the penitent to you. But mine honesty,
Shall not make poor my greatness, nor my power
Work without it. Truth is, that Fuluia,
To have me out of Egypt, made Wars here,
For which myself, the ignorant motive, do
So far ask pardon, as befits mine Honour
To stoop in such a case.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: It is Noble spoken.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.l: If it might please you, to enforce no further
The griefs between ye: to forget them quite,
Were to remember: that the present need,
Speaks to atone you.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Worthily spoken Mecenas.

sp.speaker: Enobar.
sp.p:
Or if you borrow one another's Love for the
instant, you may when you hear no more words of
Pompey return it again: you shall have time to wrangle
in:, when you have nothing else to do.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thou art a Soldier, only speak no more.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: That truth should be silent, I had almost forgot.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p:
You wrong this presence, therefore speak no:
more.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: Go to: then: your Considerate stone.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: I do not much dislike the matter, but
The manner of his sp: for it cannot be,
We shall remain in friendship, our conditions
So differing in their acts. Yet if I knew,
What Hoop should hold us staunch from edge to edge
Of the world: I would pursue it.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Give me leave Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Speak Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.p:
Thou hast a Sister by the Mothers side, admired
Octauia: Great Mark Anthony is now a widower.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
Say not, say Agrippa; if Cleopater heard you, your
proof were well deserved of rashness.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p:
I am not married Cæsar: let me hear Agrippa
further speak.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: To hold you in perpetual amity,
To make you Brothers, and to knit your hearts
With an un-slipping knot, take Anthony,
Octauia to his wife: whose beauty claims
No worse a husband than the best of men: whose
Virtue, and whose general graces, speak
That which none else can utter. By this marriage,
All little Jealousies which now seem great,
And all great fears, which now import their dangers,
Would then be nothing. Truths would be tales,
Where now half tales be truths: her love to both,
Would each to other, and all loves to both
Draw after her. Pardon what I have spoke,
For it is a studied not a present thought,
By duty ruminated.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Will Cæsar speak?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Not till he hears how Anthony is touched,
With what is spoke already.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What power is in Agrippa,
If I would say Agrippa, be it so:,
To make this good?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: The power of Cæsar,
And his power, unto Octauia.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: May I never
(To this good purpose, that so fairly shows)
Dream of impediment: let me have thy hand
Further this act of Grace: and from this hour,
The heart of Brothers govern in our Loves,
And sway our great Designs.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: There is my hand:
A Sister I bequeath you, whom no Brother
Did ever love so dearly. Let her live
To join our kingdoms, and our hearts, and never
Fly off our Loves again.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Happily, Amen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I did not think to draw my Sword against Pompey,
For he hath laid strange courtesies, and great
Of late upon: me. I must thank him only,
Least my remembrance, suffer ill report:
At heel of that, defy him.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Time calls upon us,
Of us must Pompey presently be sought,
Or else he seeks out us.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Where lies he?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: About the Mount-Mesena.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What is his strength by land?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Great, and increasing:
But by Sea he is an absolute Master.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: So is the Fame.
Would we had spoke together. Haste we for it,
Yet ere we put ourselves in Arms, dispatch we
The business we have talked of.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: With most gladness,
And do invite you to my Sisters view,
Whether straight I will lead you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Let us Lepidus not lack your company.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Noble Anthony, not sickness should detain
me.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.p: Welcome from Egypt Sir.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Half the heart of Cæsar, worthy Mecenas. My
honourable Friend Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.p: Good Enobarbus.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.p:
We have cause to be glad, that matters are so
well digested: you staid well by it in Egypt.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Aye Sir, we did sleep day out of countenance:
and made the night light with drinking.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.p:
Eight Wild-Boars roasted whole at a break-fast:
and but twelve persons there. Is this true?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
This was but as a Fly by an Eagle: we had much
more monstrous matter of Feast, which worthily deserved
noting.

sp.speaker: Mecenas.
sp.p:
She is a most triumphant Lady, if report be
square to her.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
When she first met Marke Anthony, she pursed
up:his heart upon: the River of Sidnis.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.p:
There she appeared indeed: or my reporter devised
well for her.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: I will tell you,
The Barge she sat in:, like a burnished Throne
Burnt on the water: the Poop was beaten Gold,
Purple the Sails: and so perfumed that
The Winds were Love-sick.
With them the Hours were Silver,
Which to the tune of Flutes kept stroke, and made
The water which they beat, to follow faster;
As amorous of their strokes. For her own person,
It beggared all description, she did lie
In her Pavilion, cloth of Gold, of Tissue,
Over-picturing that Venus, where we see
The fancy out-work Nature. On each side her,
Stood pretty Dimpled Boys, like smiling Cupids,
With divers coloured Fans whose wind did seem,
To glove the delicate cheeks which they did cool,
And what they undid did.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: O rare for Anthony.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Her Gentlewoman, like the Nereides,
So many Mermaids tended her in the eyes,
And made their bends adornings. At the Helm,
A seeming Mermaid steers: The Silken Tackle,
Swell with the touches of those Flower-soft hands,
That yarely frame the office. From the Barge
A strange invisible perfume hits the sense
Of the adjacent Wharves. The City cast
Her people out upon: her: and Anthony
Enthroned in the Market-place, did sit alone,
Whistling to the ayre: which but for vacancy,
Had gone to gaze on Cleopater too,
And made a gap in Nature.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Rare Egyptian.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Upon: her landing, Anthony sent to her,
Invited her to Supper: she replied,
It should be better, he became her guest:
Which she entreated, our Courteous Anthony,
Whom never the word of no woman hard speak,
Being barbered ten times over, goes to the Feast;
And for his ordinary, pays his heart,
For what his eyes eat only.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Royal Wench:
She made great Cæsar lay his Sword to bed,
He ploughed her, and she cropped.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: I saw her once
Hop forty Paces through the public street,
And having lost her breath, she spoke, and panted,
That she did make defect, perfection,
And breathless power breath forth.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.l: Now Anthony, must leave her utterly.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Never he will not:
Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale
Her infinite variety: other women cloy
The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry,
Where most she satisfies. For vildest things
Become themselves in her, that the holy Priests
Bless her, when she is Riggish.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.l: If Beauty, Wisdom, Modesty, can settle
The heart of Anthony: Octauia is
A blessed Lottery to him.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
Let us go. Good Enobarbus, make yourself
my guest, whilst you abide here.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Humbly Sir I thank you.

div2.stage: Enter Anthony, Cæsar, Octauia betweene them.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: The world, and my great office, will
Sometimes divide me from your bosom.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p:
All which time, before the Gods my knee shall
bow my prayers to them for you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Goodnight Sir. My Octauia
Read not my blemishes in the worlds report:
I have not kept my square, but that to come
Shall all be done by the Rule: good night dear Lady:
Good night Sir.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Goodnight.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Now sirra: you do wish yourself in Egypt?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.p:
Would I had never come from thence, nor you
thither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If you can, your reason?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: I see it in my motion: have it not in my tongue,
But yet hie you to Egypt again.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Say to me, whose Fortunes shall rise higher
Cæsars or mine?

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: Cæsars. Therefore
(o Anthony) stay not by his side
Thy Dæmon that thy spirit which keeps thee, is
Noble, Courageous, high unmatchable,
Where Cæsars is not. But near him, thy Angel
Becomes a fear: as being overpowered, therefore
Make space enough between you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Speak this no more.

sp.speaker: Sooth.
sp.l: To none but thee no more but: when to thee,
If thou dost play with him at any game,
Thou art sure to lose: And of that Natural luck,
He beats thee against the odds. Thy Luster thickens,
When he shines by:: I say again, thy spirit
Is all afraid to govern thee near him:
But he always it is Noble.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Get thee gone:
Say to Ventigius I would speak with him.
He shall to Parthia, be it Art or hap,
He hath spoken true. The very Dice obey him,
And in our sports my better cunning faints,
Under his chance, if we draw lots he speeds,
His Cocks do win the Battle, still of mine,
When it is all to naught: and his Quails ever
Beat mine (in hooped) at odds. I will to Egypt
And though I make this marriage for my peace,
In the east my pleasure lies. O come Ventigius.
You must to Parthia, your Commission is ready:
Follow me, and reciue it .

sp.speaker: Lepidus.
sp.p:
Trouble yourselves no further: pray you
hasten your Generals after.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
Sir, Marke Anthony, will even but kiss Octauia,
and we will: follow.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Till I shall see you in your Soldiers dress,
Which will become you both: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.p:
We shall: as I conceive the journey, be at
Mount before you Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.p:
Your way is shorter, my purposes do draw me
much about, you will: win two days upon: me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Sir good success.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.p: Farewell.

div2.stage: Enter Cleopater, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Give me some Music: Music, moody food
of us that trade in Love.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: The Music, ho.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Let it alone, let us to Billiards: come Charmian.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My arm is sore, best play with Mardian.

sp.speaker: Cleopa.
sp.p:
As well a woman with an Eunuch played, as
with a woman. Come you will: play with me Sir?

sp.speaker: Mardi.
sp.p: As well as I can Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: And when good will is showed,
Though it come too short
The Actor may plead pardon. I will none now,
Give me mine Angle, we will: to the Riuer there
My Music playing far off. I will betray
Tawny fine fishes, my bended hook shall pierce
Their slimy iawes: and as I draw them up:,
I will think them every one an Anthony,
And say, ah ha; you are caught.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
It was merry when you wagered on your Angling,
when your diver did hang a salt fish on his hook
which he with fervency drew up:.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: That time? O times:
I laughed him out of patience: and that night
I laughed him into patience, and next morn,
Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed:
Then put my Tires and Mantles on him, whilst
I wore his Sword Phillippan. O from Italie,
Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears,
That long time have been barren.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Anthony is dead.
If thou say so Villain, thou killest thy Mistress:
But well and free, if thou so yield him.
There is Gold, and here
My blue-est veins to kiss: a hand that Kings
Have lipped, and trembled kissing.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: First Madam, he is well.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Why there is more Gold.
But sirra mark, we use
To say, the dead are well: bring it to that,
The Gold I give thee, will I melt and pour
Down thy ill uttering throat.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Good Madam hear me.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Well, go to: I will::
But there is no goodness in thy face if Anthony
Be free and healthful; so tart a favour
To trumpet such good tidings. If not well,
Thou shouldest come like a Fury crowned with Snakes,
Not like a formal man.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Will it please you hear me?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speakest:
Yet if thou say Anthony lives, it is well,
Or friends with Cæsar, or not Captive to him,
I will set thee in a shower of Gold, and hail
Rich Pearls upon: thee.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Madam, he is well.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Well said.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: And Friends with Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Thou art an honest man.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Cæsar, and he, are greater Friends than ever.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Make thee a Fortune from me.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: But yet Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I do not like but yet, it does allay
The good precedence, fie upon: but yet,
But yet is as a Jailer to bring forth
Some monstrous Malefactor. Prithee Friend,
Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear,
The good and bad together: he is friends with Cæsar,
In state of health thou sayst, and thou sayst, free.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Free Madam, no: I made no such report,
He is bound unto Octauia.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: For what good turn?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: For the best turn in the bed.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am pale Charmian.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Madam, he is married to Octauia.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: The most infectious Pestilence upon: thee.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Good Madam patience.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What say you?
Hence horrible Villain, or I will spurn thine eyes
Like balls before me: I will unhair thy head,
sp.stage: She hales him vp: and downe.
sp.l: Thou shalt be whipped with Wire, and stewed in brine,
Smarting in lingering pickle.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Gracious Madam,
I that do bring the news, made not the match.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Say it is not so:, a Province I will give thee,
And make thy Fortunes proud: the blow thou hadst
Shall make thy peace, for moving me to rage,
And I will boot thee with what gift beside
Thy modesty can beg.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: He is married Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Rogue, thou hast lived too long.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Nay then I will run:
What mean you Madam, I have made no fault.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good Madam keep yourself within yourself,
The man is innocent.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Some Innocents scape not the thunderbolt:
Melt Egypt into Nyle: and kindly creatures
Turn all to Serpents. Call the slave again,
Though I am mad, I will not byte him: Call?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: He is afeared to come.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I will not hurt him,
These hands do lack Nobility, that they strike
A meaner than myself: since I myself
Have given myself the cause. Come hither Sir.
Though it be honest, it is never good
To bring bad news: give to a gracious Message
An host of tongues, but let ill tidings tell
Themselves, when they be felt.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: I have done my duty.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Is he married?
I cannot hate thee worser than I do,
If thou again say yes.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: He is married Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: The Gods confound thee,
Dost thou hold there still?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Should I lie Madam?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O, I would thou didst:
So my Egypt were submerged and made
A Cistern for scaled Snakes. Go get thee hence,
Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face to me,
Thou wouldst appear most ugly: He is married?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: I crave your Highness pardon.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He is married?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Take no offence, that I would not offend you,
To punish me for what you make me do
Seems much unequal, he is married to Octauia.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O that his fault should make a knave of thee,
That art not what thou art sure of. Get thee hence,
The Merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome
Are all too dear for me:
Lie they upon: thy hand, and be undone by them.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good your Highness patience.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: In praising Anthony,
I have dispraised Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Many times Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I am paid for it now: lead me from hence,
I faint, o Iras, Charmian: it is no matter.
Go to the Fellow, good Alexas bid him
Report the feature of Octauia: her years,
Her inclination, let him not leave out
The colour of her hair. Bring me word quickly,
Let him forever go, let him not Charmian,
Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon,
The other ways a Mars. Bid you Alexas
Bring me word, how tall she is: pity me Charmian,
But do not speak to me. Lead me to my Chamber.

div2.stage:
Flourish. Enter Pompey, at one doore with Drum and Trum-pet:
at another Cæsar, Lepidus, Anthony, Enobarbus, Me-cenas,
Agrippa, Menas with Soldiers Marching.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Your Hostages I have, so have you mine:
And we shall talk before we fight.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Most meet that first we come to words,
And therefore have we
Our written purposes before us sent,
Which if thou hast considered, let us know,
If it will: tie up: thy discontented Sword,
And carry back to Cicelie much tall youth,
That else must perish here.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: To you all three,
The Senators alone of this great world,
Chief Factors for the Gods. I do not know,
Wherefore my Father should revengers want,
Having a Son and Friends, since Iulius Cæsar,
Who at Phillippi the good Brutus ghosted,
There saw you labouring for him. What was it
That moved pale Cassius to conspire? And what
Made all-honoured, honest, Roman Brutus,
With the armed rest, Courtiers of beauteous freedom,
To drench the Capital, but that they would
Have one man but a man, and that is it
Hath made me rig my Navy. At whose burthen,
The angered Ocean foams, with which I meant
To scourge the ingratitude, that despiteful Rome
Cast on my Noble Father.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Take your time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou canst not fear us Pompey with thy sails.
We will: speak with thee at Sea. At land thou knowest
How much we do over-count thee.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: At Land indeed
Thou dost overcount me of my Fathers house:
But since the Cuckoo builds not for himself,
Remain in it as thou mayst.

sp.speaker: Lepi.
sp.l: Be pleased to tell us,
(For this is from the present how you take)
The offers we have sent you.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: There is the point.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Which do not be entreated to,
But weigh what it is worth embraced

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: And what may follow to try a larger Fortune.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: You have made me offer
Of Cicelie, Sardinia: and I must
Rid all the Sea of Pirates. Then, to send
Measures of Wheat to Rome: this greed upon:,
To part with unhacked edges, and bear back
Our Targes undinted.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: That is our offer.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Know then I came before you here,
A man prepared
To take this offer. But Marke Anthony,
Put me to some impatience: though I lose
The praise of it by telling. You must know
When Cæsar and your Brother were at blows,
Your Mother came to Cicelie, and did find
Her welcome Friendly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have heard it Pompey,
And am well studied for a liberal thanks,
Which I do owe you.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Let me have your hand:
I did not think Sir, to have met you here,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The beds in the East are soft, and thanks to you,
That called me timelier than my purpose hither:
For I have gained by it.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Since I saw you last, there is a change upon: you.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Well, I know not,
What counts harsh Fortune casts upon: my face,
But in my bosom shall she never come,
To make my heart her vassal.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Well met here.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I hope so Lepidus, thus we are agreed:
I crave our composition may be written
And sealed between us,

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: That is the next to do.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: We will: feast each other, ere we part, and let us
Draw lots who shall begin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That will I Pompey.

sp.speaker: Pompey.
sp.p:
No Anthony take the lot: but first or last,
your fine Egyptian cookery shall have the fame, I have
heard that Iulius Cæsar, grew fat with feasting there.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: You have heard much.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I have fair meaning Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And fair words to them.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Then so much have I heard,
And I have heard Appolodorus carried -;

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: No more that he did so:.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: What I pray you?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: A certain Queen to Cæsar in a Matris.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I know thee now, how farest thou Soldier?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Well, and well am like to do, for I perceive
Four Feasts are toward.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Let me shake thy hand,
I never hated thee: I have seen thee fight,
When I have envied thy behaviour.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Sir, I never loved you much, but I have praised ye,
When you have well deserved ten times as much,
As I have said you did.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Enjoy thy plainness,
It nothing ill becomes thee:
Aboard my Galley, I invite you all.
Will you lead Lords?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Shew us the way, sir.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Come.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Thy Father Pompey would never have made this
Treaty. You, and I have known sir.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: At Sea, I think.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We have Sir.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: You have done well by water.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: And you by Land.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
I will praise any man that will praise me, though
it cannot be denied what I have done by Land.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Nor what I have done by water.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Yes something you can deny for your own
safety: you have been a great Thief by Sea.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: And you by Land.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
There I deny my Land service: but give me
your hand Menas, if our eyes had authority, here they
might take two Thieves kissing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
All men's faces are true, whatsoever their hands
are.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
But there is never a fair Woman, has a true
Face.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No slander, they steal hearts.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: We came hither to fight with you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a Drinking.
Pompey doth this day laugh away his Fortune.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: If he do, sure he cannot weep it back again.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
You have said Sir, we looked not for Marke Anthony
here, pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Cæsars Sister is called
Octauia.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: True Sir, she was the wife of Caius Marcellus.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: But she is now the wife of Marcus Anthonius.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray ye sir.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: It is true.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Then is Cæsar and he, forever knit together.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p: If I were bound to Divine of this unity, I would not Prophecy so.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
I think the policy of that purpose, made more
in the Marriage, than the love of the parties.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
I think so too. But you shall find the band
that seems to tie their friendship together, will be the
very strangler of their Amity: Octauia is of a holy, cold,
and still conversation.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Who would not have his wife so:?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Not he that himself is not so:: which is Marke
Anthony: he will to his Egyptian dish again: then shall
the sighs of Octauia blow the fire up: in Cæsar, and (as I
said before) that which is the strength of their Amity,
shall prove the immediate Author of their variance. Anthony
will use his affection where it is. He married but
his occasion here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
And thus it may be. Come Sir, will you aboard?
I have a health for you.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
I shall take it sir: we have used our Throats in
Egypt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Come, let us away.

div2.stage:
Musicke playes.
Enter two or three Seruants with a Banket.

sp.p:
Here they will: be man: some of their Plants are ill
rooted already, the least wind in the world will: blow them
down.
Lepidus is high Coloured.
They have made him drink Alms drink.

As they pinch one another by the disposition, he
cries out, no more; reconciles them to his entreaty, and
himself to the drink.

But it raises the greater war between him and his
discretion.

Why this it is to have a name in great men's Fellowship:
I had as lief have a Reed that will do me no
service, as a Partisan I could not heave.

To be called into a huge Sphere, and not to be seen
to move in it, are the holes where eyes should be, which
pitifully disaster the cheeks.

div2.stage:
A Sennet sounded.
Enter Cæsar, Anthony, Pompey, Lepidus, Agrippa, Mecenas,
Enobarbus, Menes, with other Captaines.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus do they Sir: they take the flow of the Nyle
By certain scales in the Pyramid : they know
By the height, the lowness, or the mean: If dearth
Or Foison follow. The higher Nilus swells,
The more it promises: as it ebbs, the Seedsman
Upon: the slime and Ooze scatters his grain,
And shortly comes to Harvest.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: You have strange Serpents there?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Aye Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Your Serpent of Egypt, is bred now of your mud
by the operation of your Sun: so is your Crocodile.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They are so:.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Sit, and some Wine: A health to Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: I am not so well as I should be:
But I will never out.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Not till you have slept: I fear me you will: be in
till then.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p:
Nay certainly, I have heard the Ptolomies Pyramisis
are very goodly things: without contradiction I
have heard that.

sp.speaker: Menas.
sp.l: Pompey, a word.

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.l: Say in mine ear, what is it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Forsake thy seat I do beseech thee Captain,
And hear me speak a word.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Forbear me till anon.
This Wine for Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: What manner of thing is your Crocodile?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
It is shaped sir like itself, and it is as broad as it
hath breadth; It is just so high as it is, and moves with its
own organs. It lives by that which nourisheth it, and
the Elements once out of it, it Transmigrates.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: What colour is it of?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Of its own colour too.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.p: It is a strange Serpent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is so:, and the tears of it are wet.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.p: Will this description satisfy him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
With the Health that Pompey gives him, else he
is a very Epicure.

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.l: Go hang sir, hang: tell me of that? Away:
Do as I bid you. where is this Cup I called for:?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: If for the sake of Merit thou wilt hear me,
Rise from thy stool.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: think thou art mad: the matter?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I have ever held my cap off to thy Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Thou hast served me with much faith: what is
else to say? Be jolly Lords.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: These Quick-sands Lepidus,
Keep off, them for you sink.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Wilt thou be Lord of all the world?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Wilt thou be Lord of the whole world?
That is twice.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: How should that be?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
But entertain it, and though thou think me
poor, I am the man will give thee all the world.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Hast thou drunk well.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No Pompey, I have kept me from the cup,
Thou art if thou darest be, the earthly Ioue:
Whatever the Ocean pales, or sky inclips,
Is thine, if thou will: have it.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Show me which way?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: These three World-sharers, these Competitors
Are in thy vessel. Let me cut the Cable,
And when we are put off, fall to their throats:
All there is thine.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Ah, this thou shouldest have done,
And not have spoke of it.
In me it is villainy,
In thee, it had been good service: thou must know,
It is not my profit that does lead mine Honour:
Mine Honour it, Repent that ere thy tongue,
Hath so betrayed thine act. Being done unknown,
I should have found it afterwards well done,
But must condemn it now: desist, and drink.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: For this, I will never follow
Thy pawled Fortunes more,
Who seeks and will not take, when once it is offered,
Shall never find it more.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: This health to Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bear him ashore,
I will pledge it for him Pompey.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Here is to thee Menas.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Enobarbus, welcome.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Fill till the cup be hid.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: There is a strong Fellow Menas.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
He bears the third part of the world man: seest
not?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
The third part, then he is drunk: would it were
all, that it might go on wheels.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: Drink thou: increase the Reels.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: This is not yet an Alexandrian Feast.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It ripens towards it: strike the Vessels ho.
Here is to Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
I could well forbear it, it is monstrous labour
when I wash my brain, and it grow fouler.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be a Child of the time.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.p:
Possess it, I will make answer: but I had rather
fast from all, four days, than drink so much in one.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Ha my brave Emperor, shall we dance now
the Egyptian Bacchanals, and celebrate our drink?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Let us have it good Soldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, let us all take hands,
Till that the conquering Wine hath steeped our sense,
In soft and delicate Lethe.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: All take hands:
Make battery to our ears with the loud Music,
The while, I will place you, then the Boy shall sing.
The holding every man shall beat as loud,
As his strong sides can volley.

div2.stage: Musicke Playes. Enobarbus places them hand in hand.

l.emph: Come thou Monarch of the Vine,
In thy Fats our Cares be drowned
With thy Grapes our hairs be Crowned.
Cup us till the world go round
Cup us till the world go round.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: What would you more?
Pompey goodnight. Good Brother
Let me request you off. Our graver business
Frowns at this levity. Gentle Lords let us part,
You see we have burnt our cheeks. Strong Enobarbe
Is weaker than the Wine, and mine own tongue
Splits what it speaks: the wild disguise hath almost
Anticked us all. What needs more words? goodnight.
Good Anthony your hand.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I will try you on the shore.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And shall Sir, gives your hand.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: O Anthony, you have my Father house.
But what, we are Friends?
Come down into the Boat.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Take heed you fall not Menas: I will not on shore,
Nor to my Cabin: these Drums,
These Trumpets, Flutes: what
Let Neptune hear , we bid aloud farewell
To these great Fellows. Sound and be hanged, sound out.

sp.speaker: Enor.
sp.l: Ho says he there is my Cap.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Ho, Noble Captain, come.

div2.stage:
Enter Ventidius as it were in triumph, the dead body of Pacorus
borne before him.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now darting Parthya art thou stroke, and now
Pleased Fortune does of Marcus Crassus death
Make me revenger. Bear the Kings Sons body,
Before our Army, thy Pacorus Orades,
Pays this for Marcus Crassus.

sp.speaker: Romaine.
sp.l: Noble Ventidius,
Whilst yet with Parthian blood thy Sword is warm,
The Fugitive Parthians follow. Spur through Media,
Mesapotamia, and the shelters, whether
The routed fly. So thy grand Captain Anthony
Shall set thee on triumphant Chariots, and
Put Garlands on thy head.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I have done enough. A lower place note well
May make too great an act. For learn this Sillius,
Better to leave undone, than by our deed
Acquire too high a Fame, when him we serue is away.
Cæsar and Anthony, have ever won
More in their officer, than person. Sossius
One of my place in Syria, his Lieutenant,
For quick accumulation of renown,
Which he achieved by the minute, lost his favour.
Who does in the Warres more than his Captain can,
Becomes his Captains Captain: and Ambition
(The Soldiers virtue) rather makes choice of loss
Than gain, which darkens him.
I could do more to do Anthonius good,
But it would offend him. And in his offence,
Should my performance perish.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
Thou hast Ventidius that, without the which a
Soldier and his Sword grants scarce distinction: thou
wilt write to Anthony.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I will humbly signify what in his name,
That magical word of War we have effected,
How with his Banners, and his well paid ranks,
The never-yet beaten Horse of Parthia,
We have jaded out of the Field.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Where is he now?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: He purposeth to Athens, whither with what haste
The weight we must convey with us, will permit:
We shall appear before him. On: there, pass along.

div2.stage: Enter Agrippa at one doore, Enobarbus at another.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: What are the Brothers parted?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: They have dispatched with Pompey, he is gone,
The other three are Sealing. Octauia weeps
To part from Rome: Cæsar is sad, and Lepidus
Since Pompey's feast, as Menas says, is troubled
With the green sickness.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: It is a Noble Lepidus.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: A very fine one: o, how he loves Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Nay but how dearly he adores Mark Anthony.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Cæsar? why he is the Iupiter of men.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What is Anthony, the God of Iupiter?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Spake you of Cæsar? How, the nonpareil?

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: O Anthony, o thou Arabian Bird!

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Would you praise Cæsar, say Cæsar go no further.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.l: Indeed he plied them both with excellent praises.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: But he loves Cæsar best, yet he loves Anthony:
Ho, Hearts, Tongues, Figure,
Scribes, Bards, Poets, cannot
Think speak, cast, write, sing, number: ho,
His love to Anthony. But as for Cæsar,
Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Both he loves.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: They are his Shards, and he their Beetle, so::
This is to horse: Adieu, Noble Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Good Fortune worthy Soldier, and farewell.

div2.stage: Enter Cæsar, Anthony, Lepidus, and Octauia.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: No further Sir.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: You take from me a great part of myself:
Use me well in it. Sister, prove such a wife
As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest Band
Shall pass on thy approof: most Noble Anthony,
Let not the piece of Virtue which is set
Betwixt us, as the Cement of our love
To keep it builded, be the Ram to batter
The Fortress of it: for better might we
Have loved without this mean, if on both parts
This be not cherished.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Make me not offended, in your distrust.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: I have said.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You shall not find,
Though you be therein curious, the lest cause
For what you seem to fear, so the Gods keep you,
And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends:
We will here part.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Farewell my dearest Sister, fare thee well,
The Elements be kind to thee, and make
Thy spirits all of comfort: fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: My Noble Brother.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: The April is in her eyes, it is Loves spring,
And these the showers to bring it on:: be cheerful.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Sir, look well to my Husbands house: and;

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: What Octauia?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: I will tell you in your ear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can
Her heart inform her tongue.
The Swans down feather
That stands upon: the Swell at the full of Tide:
And neither way inclines.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Will Cæsar weep?

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.l: He has a cloud in his face.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
He were the worse for that were he a Horse, so is
he being a man.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Why Enobarbus:
When Anthony found Iulius Cæsar dead,
He cried almost to roaring: And he wept,
When at Phillippi he found Brutus slain.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: That year indeed, he was troubled with a rheum,
What willingly he did confound, he wailed,
Beleeu it till I weep too.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: No sweet Octauia,
You shall hear from me still: the time shall not
Out-go my thinking on you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come Sir, come,
I will wrestle with you in my strength of love,
Look here I have you, thus I let you go,
And give you to the Gods.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Adieu, be happy.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Let all the number of the Stars give light
To thy fair way.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Farewell.

div2.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Where is the Fellow?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Half afeared to come.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Go to:, go to:: Come hither Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Good Majesty: Herod of Jury dare not look
upon: you, but when you are well pleased.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
That Herods head, I will have: but how? When
Anthony is gone, through whom I might command it:
Come thou near.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Most gracious Majesty.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Didst thou behold Octauia?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Aye dread Queen.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p:
Madam in Rome, I looked her in the face: and
saw her led between her Brother, and Marke Anthony.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Is she as tall as me?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: She is not Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
Didst hear her speak?
Is she shrill tongued or low?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Madam, I heard her speak, she is low voiced.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
That is not so good: he
cannot like her long.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Like her? O Isis: it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: I think so Charmian: dull of tongue, and dwarfish
sp.l: What Majesty is in her gate, remember
If ever thou lookest on Majesty.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: She creeps: her motion, and her station are as one:
She shows a body, rather than a life,
A Statue, than a Breather.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Is this certain?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Or I have no observance.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Three in Egypt cannot make better note.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He is very knowing, I do perceive it,
There is nothing in her yet.
The Fellow has good judgment.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Guess at her years, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Madam, she was a widow.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Widow? Charmian, hark.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: And I do think she is thirty.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Bearest thou her face in mind? is it long or round?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Round, even to faultiness.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
For the most part too, they are foolish that are
so:. Her hair what colour?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Brown Madam: and her forehead
As low as she would wish it.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: There is Gold for thee,
Thou must not take my former sharpness ill,
I will employ thee back again: I find thee
Most fit for business. Go, make thee ready,
Our Letters are prepared.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: A proper man.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Indeed he is so:: I repent me much
That so I harried him. Why methinks by him,
This Creature is no such thing.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Nothing Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
The man hath seen some Majesty, and should
know.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Hath he seen Majesty? Isis else defend: and
serving you so long.

sp.speaker: Cleopa.
sp.p:
I have one thing more to ask him yet good
Charmian: but it is no matter, thou shalt bring him to me
where I will write; all may be well enough.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I warrant you Madam.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, nay Octauia, not only that,
That were excusable, that and thousands more
Of semblable import, but he hath waged
New Wars against Pompey. Made his will:, and read it,
To public ear, spoke scantily of me,
When perforce he could not
But pay me terms of Honour: cold and sickly
He vented then most narrow measure: lent me,
When the best hint was given him: he not took it,
Or did it from his teeth.

sp.speaker: Octaui.
sp.l: O my good Lord,
Believe not all, or if you must believe,
Stomach not all. A more unhappy Lady,
If this division chance, never stood between
Praying for both parts:
The good Gods will mock me presently,
When I shall pray: O bless my Lord, and Husband,
Undo that prayer, by crying out as loud,
O bless my Brother. Husband win, win Brother,
Prays, and destroys the prayer, no midway
Betwixt these extremes at all.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Gentle Octauia,
Let your best love draw to that point which seeks
Best to preserve it: if I lose mine Honour,
I lose myself: better I were not yours
Than your so branchless. But as you requested,
Your self shall go between us, the mean time Lady,
I will raise the preparation of a War
Shall stain your Brother, make your soonest haste,
So your desires are yours.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Thanks to my Lord,
The Ioue of power make me most weak, most weak,
Your reconciler: Wars betwixt you twain would be,
As if the world should cleave, and that slain men
Should solder up: the Rift.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: When it appears to you where this begins,
Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults
Can never be so equal, that your love
Can equally move with them. Provide your going,
Choose your own company, and command what cost
Your heart he is mind to:.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: How now Friend Eros?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.p: There is strange News come Sir.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: What man?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Cæsar and Lepidus have made wars upon: Pompey.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: This is old, what is the success?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.p:
Cæsar having made use of him in the wars
against Pompey: presently denied him rivalry, would not
let him partake in the glory of the action, and not resting
here, accuses him of Letters he had formerly wrote to
Pompey. Upon: his own appeal seizes him, so the poor
third is up:, till death enlarge his Confine.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p:
Then would thou hadst a pair of chaps no more,
and throw between them all the food thou hast, they will:
grind the other. where is Anthony?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: He is walking in the garden thus, and spurns
The rush that lies before him. Cries Fool Lepidus,
And threats the throat of that his Officer,
That murdered Pompey.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Our great Navy is rigged.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: For Italy and Cæsar, more Domitius,
My Lord desires you presently: my News
I might have told hereafter.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.p: It will be naught, but let it be: bring me to Anthony.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.p: Come Sir,

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Contemning Rome he has done all this, and more
In Alexandria: here is the manner of it:
In the Market-place on a Tribunal silvered,
Cleopatra and himself in Chairs of Gold
Were publicly enthroned: at the feet, sat
Cæsarion whom they call my Fathers Son,
And all the unlawful issue, that their Lust
Since then hath made between them. Unto her,
He gave the establishment of Egypt, made her
Of lower Syria, Cyprus, Lydia, absolute Queen.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.l: This in the public eye?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: In the common show place, where they exercise,
His Sons hither proclaimed the King of Kings,
Great Media, Parthia, and Armenia
He gave to Alexander. To Ptolomy he assigned,
Syria, Silicia, and Phoenetia: she
In the abiliments of the Goddess Isis
That day appeared, and oft before gave audience,
As it is reported so:.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.l: Let Rome be thus informed.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Who queasy with his insolence already,
Will their good thoughts call from him.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: The people knows it,
And have now received his accusations.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Who does he accuse?

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Cæsar, and that having in Cicilie
Sextus Pompeius spoiled, we had not rated him
His part of the Isle. Then does he say, he lent me
Some shipping unrestored. Lastly, he frets
That Lepidus of the Triumvirate, should be deposed,
And being that, we detain all his Revenue.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Sir, this should be answered.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: It is done already, and the Messenger gone:
I have told him
Lepidus was grown too cruel,
That he his high Authority abused,
And did deserve his change: for what I have conquered,
