I grant him part: but then in his Armenia,
And other of his conquered Kingdoms, I demand the like

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: He will never yield to that.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Nor must not then be yielded to in this.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Hail Cæsar, and my Lord hail most dear Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: That ever I should call thee Cast-away.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: You have not called me so:, nor have you cause.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Why have you stolen upon: us thus? you come not
Like Cæsars Sister, The wife of Anthony
Should have an Army for an Usher, and
The neighs of Horse to tell of her approach,
Long ere she did appear. The trees by the way
Should have born men, and expectation fainted,
Longing for what it had not. Nay, the dust
Should have ascended to the Roof of Heaven,
Raised by your populous Troops: But you are come
A Market-maid to Rome, and have prevented
The ostentation of our love; which left unshown,
Is often left unloved: we should have met you
By Sea, and Land, supplying every Stage
With an augmented greeting.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Good my Lord,
To come thus was I not constrained, but did it
On my free-will. My Lord Marke Anthony,
Hearing that you prepared for War, acquainted
My grieved ear withal: whereon I begged
His pardon for return.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Which soon he granted,
Being an abstract between his Lust, and him.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Do not say so:, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: I have eyes upon: him, And his affairs come to me on the wind: where is he now?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: My Lord, in Athens.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: No my most wronged Sister, Cleopatra
Hath nodded him to her. He hath given his Empire
Up: to a Whore, who now are levying
The Kings of the earth for War. He hath assembled,
Bochus the King of Lybia, Archilaus
Of Cappadocia, Philadelphos King
Of Paphlagonia: the Thracian King Adullas,
King Manchus of Arabia, King of Pont,
Herod of Jewry, Mithridates King
Of Comageat, Polemen and Amintas,
The Kings of Mede, and Licoania,
With a more larger List of Sceptres.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Aye me most wretched,
That have my heart parted betwixt two Friends,
That does afflict each other.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Welcome hither: your Letters did withhold our breaking forth
Till we perceived both how you were wrong led,
And we in negligent danger: cheer your heart,
Be you not troubled with the time, which drives
Over your content, these strong necessities,
But let determined things to destiny
Hold unbewailed their way. Welcome to Rome,
Nothing more dear to me: You are abused
Beyond the mark of thought: and the high Gods
To do you Justice, makes his Ministers
Of us, and those that love you. Best of comfort,
And ever welcome to us.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Welcome Lady.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: Welcome dear Madam,
Each heart in Rome does love and pity you,
Only the adulterous Anthony, most large
In his abominations, turns you off,
And gives his potent Regiment to a Trull
That noises it against us.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Is it so sir?

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Most certain: Sister welcome: pray you
Be ever known to patience. My dearest Sister.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I will be even with thee, doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: But why, why, why?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Thou hast forespoke my being in these wars,
And sayst it is not fit.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Well: is it, is it.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p:
If not, denounced against us, why should not
we be there in person.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Well, I could reply: if we should serve with
Horse and Mares together, the Horse were merely lost:
the Mares would bear a Soldier and his Horse.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Your presence needs must puzzle Anthony,
Take from his heart, take from his Brain, from his time,
What should not then be spared. He is already
Traduced for Levity, and it is said in Rome,
That Photinus an Eunuch, and your Maids
Manage this war.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sink Rome, and their tongues rot
That speak against us. A Charge we bear in the War,
And as the president of my Kingdom will
Appear there for a man. Speak not against it,
I will not stay behind.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Nay I have done, here comes the Emperor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is it not strange Camidius,
That from Tarrentum, and Brandusium,
He could so quickly cut the Ionian Sea,
And take in Troine. You have heard of it (Sweet?)

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Celerity is never more admired,
Than by the negligent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A good rebuke,
Which might have well becomed the best of men
To taunt at slackness. Camidius, we
Will fight with him by Sea.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: By Sea, what else?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Why will my Lord, do so:?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For that he dares us to it.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: So hath my Lord, dared him to single fight.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Aye, and to wage this Battle at Pharsalia,
Where Cæsar fought with
Pompey. But these offers
Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off,
And so should you.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Your Ships are not well manned,
Your Mariners are Militers, Reapers, people
Engrossed by swift Impress. In Cæsars Fleet,
Are those, that often have against Pompey fought,
Their ships are yare, yours heavy: no disgrace
Shall fall you for refusing him at Sea,
Being prepared for Land.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By Sea, by Sea.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Most worthy Sir, you therein throw away
The absolute Soldiership you have by Land,
Distract your Army, which doth most consist
Of War-marked-footmen, leave unexecuted
Your own renowned knowledge, quite forgo
The way which promises assurance, and
Give up: yourself merely to chance and hazard,
From firm Security.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will fight at Sea.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I have sixty Sails, Cæsar none better.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Our over-plus of shipping will we burn,
And with the rest full manned, from the head of Action
Beat the approaching Cæsar. But if we fail,
We then can do it at Land.
Thy Business?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: The News is true, my Lord, he is descried,
Cæsar has taken Toryne.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can he be there in person? It is impossible
Strange, that his power should be. Camidius,
Our nineteen Legions thou shalt hold by Land,
And our twelve thousand Horse. We will to our Ship,
Away my Thetis.
How now worthy Soldier?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: O Noble Emperor, do not fight by Sea,
Trust not to rotten planks: Do you misdoubt
This Sword, and these my Wounds; let the Egyptians
And the Phœnicians go a ducking: we Have used to conquer standing on the earth,
And fighting foot to foot.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, well, away.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: By Hercules I think I am in the right.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Soldier thou art: but his whole action grows
Not in the power of it: so our Leaders lead,
And we are Women's men's.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.p: You keep by Land the Legions and the Horse whole, do you not?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Marcus Octauius, Marcus Iusteus, Publicola, and Celius, are for Sea:
But we keep whole by Land. This speed of Cæsars
Carries beyond belief.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: While he was yet in Rome,
His power went out in such distractions,
As beguiled all Spies.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Who is his Lieutenant, hear you?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: They say, one Towrus.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Well, I know the man.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: The Emperor calls Camidius.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: With News the times with Labour,
And throws forth each minute, some.

div2.stage: Enter Cæsar with his Army, marching.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Towrus?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Strike not by Land,
Keep whole, provoke not Battle
Till we have done at Sea. Do not exceed
The Prescript of this Scroll: Our fortune lies
Upon: this jump.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Set we our Squadrons on yond side of the Hill,
In eye of Caesar's battle, from which place
We may the number of the Ships behold,
And so proceed accordingly.

div2.stage:
Camidius Marcheth with his Land Army one way ouer the
stage, and Towrus the Lieutenant of Cæsar the other way:
After their going in:, is heard the noise of a Sea fight.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Naught, naught, all naught, I can behold no longer:
The Antoniad, the Egyptian Admiral,
With all their sixty fly, and turn the Rudder:
To see it, mine eyes are blasted.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Gods, and Goddesses, all the whole synod of them!

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: What is thy passion.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: The greater Cantle of the world, is lost
With very ignorance, we have kissed away
Kingdoms, and Provinces.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: How appears the Fight?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: On our side, like the Tokened Pestilence,
Where death is sure. Yon ribaudred Nag of Egypt,
(Whom Leprosy overtake) in the midst of the fight,
When vantage like a pair of Twins appeared
Both as the same, or rather ours the elder;
(The Breeze upon: her) like a Cow in June,
Hoists Sails, and flies.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: That I beheld:
Mine eyes did sicken at the sight, and could not
Endure a further view.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: She once being loosed,
The Noble ruin of her Magic, Anthony,
Claps on his Sea-wing, and (like a doting Mallard)
Leaving the Fight in heighth, flies after her:
I never saw an Action of such shame;
Experience, Man-hood, Honour, never before,
Did violate so itself.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Alack, alack.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Our Fortune on the Sea is out of breath,
And sinks most lamentably. Had our General
Been what he knew himself, it had gone well:
O his has given example for our flight,
Most grossly by his own.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.p:
Aye, are you thereabouts? Why then goodnight
indeed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: It is easy to it,
And there I will attend what further comes.

sp.speaker: Camid.
sp.l: To Cæsar will I render
My Legions and my Horse, six Kings already
Show me the way of yielding.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: I will yet follow
The wounded chance of Anthony, though my reason
Sits in the wind against me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hark, the Land bids me tread no more upon it,
It is ashamed to bear me. Friends, come hither,
I am so lated in the world, that I
Have lost my way forever. I have a ship,
Laden with Gold, take that, divide it: fly,
And make your peace with Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Fly? Not we.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have fled myself, and have instructed cowards
To run, and show their shoulders. Friends be gone,
I have myself resolved upon a course,
Which has no need of you. Be gone,
My Treasure is in the Harbour. Take it: O,
I followed that I blush to look upon:,
My very hairs do mutiny: for the white
Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them
For fear, and doting. Friends be gone, you shall
Have Letters from me to some Friends, that will
Sweep your way for you. Pray you look not sad,
Nor make replies of loathness, take the hint
Which my despair proclaims. Let them be left
Which leaves itself, to the Sea-side straight way;
I will possess you of that ship and Treasure.
Leave me, I pray a little: pray you now,
Nay do so:: for indeed I have lost command,
Therefore I pray you, I will see you by and by:.

div2.stage: Enter Cleopatra led by Charmian and Eros.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Nay gentle Madam, to him, comfort him.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Do most dear Queen.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Do, why, what else?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Let me sit down: O Iuno.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, no, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: See you here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Madam, o good Empress.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Sir, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, yes; he at Philippi kept
His sword even like a dancer, while I struck
The lean and wrinkled Cassius, and it was I
That the mad Brutus ended: he alone
Dealt on Lieutenantry, and no practise had
In the brave squares of War: yet now: no matter.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Ah stand by:.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: The Queen my Lord, the Queen.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Go to him, Madam, speak to him,
He is unqualitied with very shame.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Well then, sustain me: O.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Most Noble Sir arise, the Queen approaches,
Her head is declined, and death will cease her, but
Your comfort makes the rescue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have offended Reputation,
A most unnoble swerving.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Sir, the Queen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O whether hast thou lead me Egypt, see
How I convey my shame, out of thine eyes,
By looking back what I have left behind
Destroyed in dishonour.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O my Lord, my Lord,
Forgive my fearful sails, I little thought
You would have followed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Egypt, thou knewest too well,
My heart was to thy Rudder tied by the strings,
And thou shouldst tow me after. Over my spirit
The full supremacy thou knewest, and that
Thy beck, might from the bidding of the Gods
Command me.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O my pardon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now I must
To the young man send humble Treaties, dodge
And palter in the shifts of lowness, who
With half the bulk of the world played as I pleased,
Making, and marring Fortunes. You did know
How much you were my Conqueror, and that
My Sword, made weak by my affection, would
Obey it on all cause.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Pardon, pardon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fall not a tear I say, one of them rates
All that is won and lost: Give me a kiss,
Even this repays me.
We sent our Schoolmaster, is he come back?
Love I am full of Lead: some Wine
Within there, and our Viands: Fortune knows,
We scorn her most, when most she offers blows.

div2.stage: Enter Cæsar, Agrippa, and Dollabello, with others.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Let him appear that is come from Anthony.
Know you him.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Cæsar, it is his Schoolmaster,
An argument that he is plucked, when hither
He sends so poor a Pinion of his Wing,
Which had superfluous Kings for Messengers,
Not many Moons gone by:.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Approach, and speak.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Such as I am, I come from Anthony:
I was of late as petty to his ends,
As is the Morn-dew on the Myrtle leaf
To his grand Sea.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Be it so:, declare thine office.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Lord of his Fortunes he salutes thee, and
Requires to live in Egypt, which not granted
He Lessons his Requests, and to thee sues
To let him breath between the Heavens and Earth
A private man in Athens: this for him.
Next, Cleopatra does confess thy Greatness,
Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves
The Circle of the Ptolomies for her heirs,
Now hazarded to thy Grace.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: For Anthony,
I have no ears to his request. The Queen,
Of Audience, nor Desire shall fail, so she
From Egypt drive her all-disgraced Friend,
Or take his life there. This if she perform,
She shall not sue unheard. So to them both.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Fortune pursue thee.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Bring him through the Bands:
To try thy Eloquence, now it is time, dispatch,
From Anthony win Cleopatra, promise
And in our Name, what she requires, add more
From thine invention, offers. Women are not
In their best Fortunes strong; but want will perjure
The never touched Vestal. Try thy cunning Thidias,
Make thine own Edict for thy pains, which we
Will answer as a Law.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: Cæsar. I go.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Observe how Anthony becomes his flaw,
And what thou thinkst his very action speaks
In every power that moves.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: Cæsar, I shall.

div2.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Charmian, and Iras.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What shall we do, Enobarbus?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Think, and die.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Is Anthony, or we in fault for this?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Anthony only, that would make his will
Lord of his Reason. What though you fled,
From that great face of War, whose several ranges
Frighted each other? Why should he follow?
The itch of his Affection should not then
Have nicked his Captain-ship, at such a point,
When half to half the world opposed, he being
The mered question? It was a shame no less
Than was his loss, to course your flying Flags,
And leave his Navy gazing.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Prithee peace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is that his answer?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Queen shall then have courtesy,
So she will yield us up:.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He says so:.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p:
Let her know it. To the Boy Cæsar send this
grizzled head, and he will fill thy wishes to the brim,
With Principalities.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: That head my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To him again, tell him he wears the Rose
Of youth upon: him: from which, the world should note
Something particular: His Coin, Ships, Legions,
May be a Cowards, whose Ministers would prevail
Under the service of a Child, as soon
As in the Command of Cæsar. I dare him therefore
To lay his gay Comparisons apart,
And answer me declined, Sword against Sword,
Ourselves alone: I will write it: Follow me.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Yes like enough: hie battled Cæsar will
Unstate his happiness, and be Staged to the show
Against a Shorter. I see men's Judgments are
A parcel of their Fortunes, and things outward
Do draw the inward quality after them
To suffer all alike, that he should dream,
Knowing all measures, the full Cæsar will
Answer his emptiness; Cæsar thou hast subdued
His judgment too.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: A Messenger from Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What no more Ceremony? See my Women,
Against the blown Rose may they stop their nose,
That kneeled unto the Buds. Admit him sir.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Mine honesty, and I, begin to square,
The Loyalty well held to Fools, does make
Our Faith mere folly: yet he that can endure
To follow with Allegiance a fallen Lord,
Does conquer him that did his Master conquer,
And earns a place in the Story.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Cæsars will:.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: Hear it apart.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: None but Friends: say boldly.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: So happily are they Friends to Anthony.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: He needs as many (Sir) as Cæsar has,
Or needs not us. If Cæsar please, our Master
Will leap to be his Friend: For us you know,
Whose he is, we are, and that is Cæsars.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: So:. Thus then thou most renowned, Cæsar entreats,
Not to consider in what case thou standest
Further than he is Cæsars.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Go on:, right Royal.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: He knows that you embrace not Anthony
As you did love, but as you feared him.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: The scar is upon: your Honour, therefore he
Does pity, as constrained blemishes,
Not as deserved.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He is a God,
And knows what is most right. Mine Honour
Was not yielded, but conquered merely.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: To be sure of that, I will ask Anthony.
Sir, sir, thou art so leaky
That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for
Thy dearest quit thee.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: Shall I say to Cæsar,
What you require of him: for he partly begs
To be desired to give. It much would please him,
That of his Fortunes you should make a staff
To lean upon:. But it would warm his spirits
To hear from me you had left Anthony,
And put yourself under his shroud, the universal Landlord.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: My name is Thidias.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Most kind Messenger,
Say to great Cæsar this in disputation,
I kiss his conquering hand: Tell him, I am prompt
To lay my Crown at his feet, and there to kneel.
Tell him, from his all-obeying breath, I hear
The doom of Egypt.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: It is your Noblest course:
Wisdom and Fortune combating together,
If that the former dare but what it can,
No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay
My duty on your hand.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Your Cæsars Father oft,
(When he hath mused of taking kingdoms in:)
Bestowed his lips on that unworthy place,
As it rained kisses.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Favours? By Ioue that thunders. What art thou Fellow?

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: One that but performs
The bidding of the fullest man, and worthiest
To have command obeyed.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: You will be whipped.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Approach there: ah you Kite. Now Gods and devils
Authority melts from me of late. When I cried ho,
Like Boys unto a muss, Kings would start forth,
And cry, your will:. Have you no ears?
I am Anthony yet. Take hence this Iack, and whip him.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: It is better playing with a Lions whelp,
Than with an old one dying.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Moon and Stars,
Whip him: were it twenty of the greatest Tributaries
That do acknowledge Cæsar, should I find them
So saucy with the hand of she here, what is her name
Since she was Cleopatra? Whip him Fellows,
Till like a Boy you see him cringe his face,
And whine aloud for mercy. Take him hence.

sp.speaker: Thid.
sp.l: Marke Anthony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tug him away: being whipped
Bring him again, the Iacke of Cæsars shall
Bear us an arrant to him.
You were half blasted ere I knew you: Ha?
Have I my pillow left unpressed in Rome,
Forborne the getting of a lawful Race,
And by a Gem of women, to be abused
By one that looks on Feeders?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You have been a boggler ever,
But when we in our viciousness grow hard
(O misery of it) the wise Gods seal our eyes
In our own filth, drop our clear judgments, make us
Adore our errors, laugh at us while we strut
To our confusion.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O, is it come to this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I found you as a Morsel, cold upon:
Dead Cæsars Trencher: Nay, you were a Fragment
Of Gneius Pompeyes, besides what hotter hours
Unregistered in vulgar Fame, you have
Luxuriously picked out. For I am sure,
Though you can guess what Temperance should be,
You know not what it is.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Wherefore is this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To let a Fellow that will take rewards,
And say, God quit you, be familiar with
My play-fellow, your hand; this Kingly Seal,
And plighter of high hearts. O that I were
Upon: the hill of Basan, to out-roar
The horned Heard, for I have savage cause,
And to proclaim it civilly, were like
A haltered neck, which does the Hangman thank,
For being yare about him. Is he whipt?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Soundly, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cried he? and begged a Pardon?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He did ask favour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If that thy Father live, let him repent
Thou wast not made his daughter, and be thou sorry
To follow Cæsar in his Triumph, since
Thou hast been whipped. For following him, henceforth
The white hand of a Lady Fever thee,
Shake thou to look on it. Get thee back to Cæsar,
Tell him thy entertainment: look thou say
He makes me angry with him. For he seems
Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am,
Not what he knew I was. He makes me angry,
And at this time most easy it is to do it:
When my good Stars, that were my former guides
Have empty left their Orbs, and shot their Fires
Into the Abysm of hell. If he mislike,
My sp, and what is done, tell him he has
Hiparchus, my enfranchised Bondman, whom
He may at pleasure whip, or hang, or torture,
As he shall like to quit me. Urge it thou:
Hence with thy stripes, be gone.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Have you done yet?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Alack our Terrene Moon is now Eclipsed,
And it portends alone the fall of Anthony.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I must stay his time?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To flatter Cæsar, would you mingle eyes
With one that ties his points.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Not know me yet?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cold-hearted toward me?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Ah (Dear) if I be so:,
From my cold heart let Heaven engender hail,
And poison it in the source, and the first stone
Drop in my neck: as it determines so
Dissolve my life, the next Cæsarian smile,
Till by degrees the memory of my womb,
Together with my brave Egyptians all,
By the discandying of this pelleted storm,
Lie graveless, till the Flies and Gnats of Nyle
Have buried them for prey.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am satisfied:
Cæsar sets down in Alexandria, where
I will oppose his Fate. Our force by Land,
Hath Nobly held, our severed Navy too
Have knit again, and Fleet, threatning most Sea-like.
Where hast thou been my heart? Dost thou hear Lady?
If from the Field I shall return once more
To kiss these Lips, I will appear in Blood,
I, and my Sword, will earn our Chronicle,
There is hope in it yet.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: That is my brave Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will be treble-sinewed, hearted, breathed,
And fight maliciously: for when mine hours
Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives
Of me for jests: But now, I will set my teeth,
And send to darkness all that stop me. Come,
Let us have one other gaudy night: Call to me
All my sad Captains, fill our Bowls once more:
Let us mock the midnight Bell.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: It is my Birth-day,
I had thought to have held it poor. But since my Lord
Is Anthony again, I will be Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We will yet do well.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Call all his Noble Captains to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do so:, we will speak to them,
And tonight I will force
The Wine peep through their scars.
Come on: (my Queen)
There is sap in it yet. The next time I do fight
I will make death love me: for I will contend
Even with his pestilent Scythe.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: Now he will out-stare the Lightning, to be furious
Is to be frighted out of fear, and in that mood
The Dove will peck the Estridge; and I see still
A diminution in our Captains brain,
Restores his heart; when valour prays in reason,
It eats the Sword it fights with: I will seek
Some way to leave him.

div2.stage:
Enter Cæsar, Agrippa, and Mecenas with his Army,
Cæsar reading a Letter.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: He calls me Boy, and chides as he had power
To beat me out of Egypt. My Messenger
He hath whipped with Rods, dares me to personal Combat.
Cæsar to Anthony: let the old Ruffian know,
I have many other ways to die: mean time
Laugh at his Challenge.

sp.speaker: Mece.
sp.l: Cæsar must think,
When one so great begins to rage, he is hunted
Even to falling. Give him no breath, but now
Make boot of his distraction: Never anger
Made good guard for itself.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Let our best heads know,
That tomorrow, the last of many Battles
We mean to fight. Within our Files there are,
Of those that served Marke Anthony but late,
Enough to fetch him in:. See it done,
And Feast the Army, we have store to do it,
And they have earned the waste. Poor Anthony.

div2.stage:
Enter Anthony, Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Charmian,
Iras, Alexas, with others.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He will not fight with me, Domitian?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why should he not?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune,
He is twenty men to one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tomorrow Soldier,
By Sea and Land I will fight: or I will live,
Or bathe my dying Honour in the blood
Shall make it live again. Wilt thou fight well.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: I will strike, and cry, Take all.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well said, come on::
Call forth my Household Servants, let us tonight
Be bounteous at our Meal. Give me thy hand,
Thou hast been rightly honest, so hast thou,
Thou, and thou, and thou: you have served me well,
And Kings have been your fellows.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: It is one of those odd tricks which sorrow shoots
Out of the mind.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And thou art honest too:
I wish I could be made so many men,
And all of you clapped up: together, in
An Anthony: that I might do you service,
So good as you have done.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: The Gods forbid.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, my good Fellows, wait on me tonight:
Scant not my Cups, and make as much of me,
As when mine Empire was your Fellow too,
And suffered my command.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What does he mean?

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: To make his Followers weep.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tend me tonight;
May be, it is the period of your duty,
Happily you shall not see me more, or if,
A mangled shadow. Perchance tomorrow,
You will serve another Master. I look on you,
As one that takes his leave. Mine honest Friends,
I turn you not away, but like a Master
Married to your good service, stay till death:
Tend me tonight two hours, I ask no more,
And the Gods yield you for it.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: What mean you (Sir)
To give them this discomfort? Look they weep,
And I an Ass, am Onion-eyed; for shame,
Transform us not to women.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho:
Now the Witch take me, if I meant it thus.
Grace grow where those drops fall (my hearty Friends)
You take me in too dolorous a sense,
For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you
To burn this night with Torches: Know (my hearts)
I hope well of tomorrow, and will lead you,
Where rather I will expect victorious life,
Then death, and Honour. Let us to Supper, come,
And drown consideration.

sp.speaker: 1.Sol.
sp.l: Brother, goodnight: tomorrow is the day.

sp.speaker: 2.Sol.
sp.l: It will determine one way: Fare you well.
Heard you of nothing strange about the streets.
Nothing: what news?
Belike it is but a Rumour, good night to you.
Well sir, good night.
Soldiers, have careful Watch.
And you: Goodnight, goodnight.

div2.stage: They place themselues in euery corner of the Stage.

sp.l: Here we: and if tomorrow
Our Navy thrive, I have an absolute hope
Our Landmen will stand up:.
It is a brave Army, and full of purpose.

div2.stage: Musicke of the Hoboyes is vnder the Stage.

sp.l: Peace, what noise?
List, list.
Hark.
Music in the Air.
Under the earth.
It signs well, does it not?
No.
Peace I say: What should this mean?
It is the God Hercules, whom Anthony loved,
Now leaves him.
Walk, let us see if other Watchmen
Do hear what we do?
How now Masters?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: How now? how now? do you hear this?
Aye, is it not strange?
Do you hear Masters? Do you hear?
Follow the noise so far as we have quarter.
Let us see how it will give off.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Content: It is strange.

div2.stage: Enter Anthony and Cleopatra, with others.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Eros, mine Armour Eros.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sleep a little.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No my Chuck. Eros, come mine Armour Eros.
Come good Fellow, put thine Iron on:,
If Fortune be not ours today, it is
Because we brave her. Come.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Nay, I will help too, Anthony.
What is this for:?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ah let be, let be, thou art
The Armourer of my heart: False, false: This, this,

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sooth-law I will help: Thus it must be.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, well, we shall thrive now.
Seest thou my good Fellow. Go, put on: thy defences.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Briefly Sir.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Is not this buckled well?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Rarely, rarely:
He that unbuckles this, till we do please
To daft for our Repose, shall hear a storm.
Thou fumblest Eros, and my Queen is a Squire
More tight at this, than thou: Dispatch. O Love,
That thou couldst see my Wars today, and knewest
The Royal Occupation, thou shouldst see
A Workman in it.
Good morrow to thee, welcome,
Thou lookest like him that knows a warlike Charge:
To business that we love, we rise betime,
And go to it with delight.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: A thousand Sir, early though it be, have on their
Riveted trim, and at the Port expect you.

div2.stage:
Showt.
Trumpets Flourish.
Enter Captaines, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The Morn is fair: Good morrow General.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Good morrow General.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is well blown Lads.
This Morning, like the spirit of a youth
That means to be of note, begins betimes.
So:, so:: Come give me that, this way, well-said.
Fare thee well Dame, whatever becomes of me,
This is a Soldiers kiss: rebukeable,
And worthy shameful check it were, to stand
On more Mechanic Complement, I will leave thee.
Now like a man of Steel, you that will fight,
Follow me close, I will bring you to it: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Please you retire to your Chamber?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Lead me:
He goes forth gallantly: That he and Cæsar might
Determine this great War in single fight;
Then Anthony; but now. Well on:.

div2.stage: Trumpets sound. Enter Anthony, and Eros.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: The Gods make this a happy day to Anthony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Would thou, and those thy scars had once prevailed
To make me fight at Land.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Hadst thou done so:,
The Kings that have revolted, and the Soldier
That has this morning left thee, would have still
Followed thy heels.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who is gone this morning?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Who? one ever near thee, call for Enobarbus,
He shall not hear thee, or from Cæsars Camp,
Say I am none of thine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Sir he is with Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Sir, his Chests and Treasure he has not with him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Most certain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Go Eros, send his Treasure after, do it,
Detain no jot I charge thee: write to him,
(I will subscribe) gentle adieus, and greetings;
Say, that I wish he never find more cause
To change a Master. O my Fortunes have
Corrupted honest men. Dispatch Enobarbus.

div2.stage:
Flourish. Enter Agrippa, Cæsar, with Enobarbus,
and Dollabella.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Go forth Agrippa, and begin the fight:
Our will is Anthony be took alive:
Make it so known.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Cæsar, I shall.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: The time of universal peace is near:
Prove this a prosperous day, the three nooked world
Shall bear the Olive freely.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Anthony is come into the Field.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Go charge Agrippa,
Plant those that have revolted in the Vant,
That Anthony may seem to spend his Fury
Upon: himself.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Alexas did revolt, and went to Jewry on
Affairs of Anthony, there did dissuade
Great Herod to incline himself to Cæsar,
And leave his Master Anthony. For this pains,
Cæsar hath hanged him: Camindius and the rest
That fell away, have entertainment, but
No honourable trust: I have done ill,
Of which I do accuse myself so sorely,
That I will joy no more.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Enobarbus, Anthony
Hath after thee sent all thy Treasure, with
His Bounty over-plus. The Messenger
Came on my guard, and at thy Tent is now
Unloading of his Mules.

sp.speaker: Eno.
sp.l: I give it you.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Mock not Enobarbus,
I tell you true: Best you make safe the bringer
Out of the host, I must attend mine Office,
Or would have done it myself. Your Emperor
Continues still a Ioue.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: I am alone the Villain of the earth,
And feel I am so most. O Anthony,
Thou Mine of Bounty, how wouldst thou have payed
My better service, when my turpitude
Thou dost so Crown with Gold. This blows my heart,
If swift thought break it not: a swifter mean
Shall out-strike thought, but thought will do it. I feel
I fight against thee: No I will go seek
Some Ditch, wherein to die: the foulest best fits
My latter part of life.

div2.stage:
Alarum, Drummes and Trumpets.
Enter Agrippa.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Retire, we have engaged ourselves too far:
Cæsar himself has work, and our oppression
Exceeds what we expected.

div2.stage:
Alarums.
Enter Anthony, and Scarrus wounded.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O my brave Emperor, this is fought indeed,
Had we done so at first, we had driven them home
With clouts about their heads.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou bleedest apace.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I had a wound here that was like a T,
But now it is made an H.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They do retire.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: We will beatthem into Bench-holes, I have yet
Room for six scotches more.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: They are beaten Sir, and our advantage serves
For a fair victory.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Let us score their backs,
And snatch them up:, as we take Hares behind,
It is sport to maul a Runner.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will reward thee
Once for thy sprightly comfort, and ten-fold
For thy good valour. Come thee on:.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I will halt after.

div2.stage:
Alarum. Enter Anthony againe in a March.
Scarrus, with others.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We have beat him to his Camp: Run one
Before, and let the Queen know of our guests: tomorrow
Before the Sun shall see us, we will: spill the blood
That has today escaped. I thank you all,
For doughty handed are you, and have fought
Not as you served the Cause, but as it had been
Each man's like mine: you have shown all Hectors.
Enter the City, clip your Wives, your Friends,
Tell them your feats, whilst they with joyful tears
Wash the congealment from your wounds, and kiss
The Honoured-gashes whole.
Give me thy hand,
To this great Fairy, I will commend thy acts,
Make her thanks bless thee. O thou day of the world,
Chain mine armed neck, leap thou, Attire and all
Through proof of Harness to my heart, and there
Ride on the pants triumphing.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Lord of Lords.
O infinite Virtue, comest thou smiling from
The worlds great snare uncaught.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Mine Nightingale,
We have beat them to their Beds.
What Girl, though gray
Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet have We
A Brain that nourishes our Nerves, and can
Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man,
Commend unto his Lips thy favouring hand,
Kiss it my Warrior: He hath fought today,
As if a God in hate of Mankind, had
Destroyed in such a shape.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I will give thee Friend
An Armour all of Gold: it was a Kings.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He has deserved it, were it Carbuncled
Like holy Phoebus Car. Give me thy hand,
Through Alexandria make a jolly March,
Bear our hacked Targets, like the men that owe them.
Had our great Palace the capacity
To Camp this host, we all would sup together,
And drink Carouses to the next days Fate
Which promises Royal peril, Trumpeters
With brazen din blast you the Cities ear,
Make mingle with our rattling Tambourines,
That heaven and earth may strike their sounds together,
Applauding our approach.

div2.stage: Enter a Centerie, and his Company, Enobarbus followes.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: If we be not relieved within this hour,
We must return to the Court of Guard: the night
Is shiny, and they say, we shall embattle
By the second hour in the Morn.

sp.speaker: 1.Watch.
sp.l: This last day was a shrewd one to us.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: O bear me witness night.
What man is this?
Stand close, and list him.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: Be witness to me (O thou blessed Moon)
When men revolted shall upon: Record
Bear hateful memory: poor Enobarbus did
Before thy face repent.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: Enobarbus?
Peace: Hark further.

sp.speaker: Enob.
sp.l: O Sovereign Mistress of true Melancholy,
The poisonous damp of night dispunge upon: me,
That Life, a very Rebel to my will:,
May hang no longer on me. Throw my heart
Against the flint and hardness of my fault,
Which being dried with grief, will break to powder,
And finish all foul thoughts. O Anthony,
Nobler than my revolt is Infamous,
Forgive me in thine own particular,
But let the world rank me in Register
A Master leaver, and a fugitive:
O Anthony!
O Anthony!
Let us speak to him.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: Let us hear him, for the things he speaks
May concern Cæsar.
Let us do so:; but he sleeps.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: Swoons rather, for so bad a Prayer as his
Was never yet for sleep.
Go we to him.
Awake sir, awake, speak to us.
Hear you sir?

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: The hand of death hath raught him.
Hark the Drums demurely wake the sleepers:
Let us bear him to the Court of Guard: he is of note:
Our hour is fully out.
Come on then, he may recover yet.

div2.stage: Enter Anthony and Scarrus, with their Army.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Their preparation is today by Sea,
We please them not by Land.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: For both, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would they would fight in the Fire or in the Air,
We would fight there too. But this it is, our Foot
Upon: the hills adjoining to the City
Shall stay with us. Order for Sea is given,
They have put forth the Haven:
Where their appointment we may best discover,
And look on their endeavour.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: But being charged, we will be still by Land,
Which as I take it we shall, for his best force
Is forth to Man his Galleys. To the Vales,
And hold our best advantage.

div2.stage:
Alarum afarre off, as at a Sea-fight.
Enter Anthony, and Scarrus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yet they are not joined:
Where yond Pine does stand, I shall discover all.
I will bring thee word straight, how it is like to go.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Swallows have built
In Cleopatra's Sails their nests. The Auguries
Say, they know not, they cannot tell, look grimly,
And dare not speak their knowledge. Anthony,
Is valiant, and dejected, and by starts
His fretted Fortunes give him hope and fear
Of what he has, and has not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All is lost:
This foul Egyptian hath betrayed me:
My Fleet hath yielded to the Foe, and yonder
They cast their Caps up:, and Carouse together
Like Friends long lost. Triple-turned Whore, it is thou
Hast sold me to this Novice, and my heart
Makes only Wars on thee. Bid them all fly:
For when I am revenged upon my Charm,
I have done all. Bid them all fly, be gone.
O Sun, thy uprise shall I see no more,
Fortune, and Anthony part here, even here
Do we shake hands? All come to this? The hearts
That panelled me at heels, to whom I gave
Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets
On blossoming Cæsar: And this Pine is barked,
That over-topped them all. Betrayed I am.
O this false Soul of Egypt! this grave Charm,
Whose eye beckoned forth my Wars, and called them home:
Whose Bosom was my Coronet, my chief end,
Like a right Gypsy, hath at fast and loose
Beguiled me, to the very heart of loss.
What Eros, Eros?
Ah, thou Spell! Avaunt.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Why is my Lord enraged against his Love?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving,
And blemish Cæsars Triumph. Let him take thee,
And hoist thee up: to the shouting Plebeians,
Follow his Chariot, like the greatest spot
Of all thy Sex. Most Monster-like be shown
For poorest Diminutives, for Dolts, and let
Patient Octauia, plough thy visage up:
With her prepared nails.
It is well thou art gone,
If it be well to live. But better it were
Thou fellest into my fury, for one death
Might have prevented many. Eros, ho!
The shirt of Nessus is upon: me, teach me
Alcides, thou mine Ancestor, thy rage.
Let me lodge Licas on the horns of the Moon,
And with those hands that grasped the heaviest Club,
Subdue my worthiest self: The Witch shall die,
To the young Roman Boy she hath sold me, and I fall
Under this plot: She dies for it. Eros ho?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Help me my women: O he is more mad
Than Telamon for his Shield, the Boar of Thessaly
Was never so embossed.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: To the Monument, there lock yourself,
And send him word you are dead:
The Soul and Body rive not more in parting,
Than greatness going off.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: To the Monument: Mardian, go tell him I have slain
myself:
Say, that the last I spoke was Anthony,
And word it (prithee) piteously. Hence Mardian,
And bring me how he takes my death to the Monument.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Eros, thou yet beholdest me?

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Aye Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sometime we see a cloud that is Dragonish,
A vapour sometime, like a Bear, or Lion,
A toward Citadel, a pendant Rock,
A forked Mountain, or blue Promontory
With Trees upon it, that nod unto the world,
And mock our eyes with Air.
Thou hast seen these Signs,
They are black Vespers Pageants.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That which is now a Horse, even with a thought
the Rack dislimbs, and makes it indistinct
As water is in water.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: It does my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My good Knave Eros, now thy Captain is
Even such a body: Here I am Anthony,
Yet cannot hold this visible shape (my Knave)
I made these wars for Egypt, and the Queen,
Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine:
Which whilst it was mine, had annexed unto it
A Million more, (now lost:) she Eros has
Packed Cards with Cæsars, and false played my Glory
Unto an Enemies triumph.
Nay, weep not gentle Eros, there is left us
Ourselves to end ourselves.
O thy vile Lady, she has robbed me of my Sword.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No Anthony,
My Mistress loved thee, and her Fortunes mingled
with thine entirely.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hence saucy Eunuch peace, she hath betrayed me,
And shall die the death.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Death of one person, can be paid but once,
And that she has discharged. What thou wouldst do
Is done unto thy hand: the last she spake
Was Anthony, most Noble Anthony.
Then in the midst a tearing groan did break
The name of Anthony: it was divided
Between her heart, and lips: she tendered life
Thy name so buried in her.
Dead then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Unarm Eros, the long days task is done,
And we must sleep: That thou departest hence safe
Does pay thy labour richly: Go.
Off, pluck off,
The seven-fold shield of Aiax cannot keep
The battery from my heart. O cleave my sides.
Heart, once be stronger than thy Continent,
Crack thy frail Case. Apace Eros, apace;
No more a Soldier: bruised pieces go,
You have been Nobly borne. From me awhile.
I will overtake thee Cleopatra, and
Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now
All length is Torture: since the Torch is out,
Lie down and stray no farther. Now all labour
Mars what it does: yea, very force entangles
Itself with strength: Seal then and all is done.
Eros? I come my Queen. Eros? Stay for me,
Where Souls do couch on Flowers, we will: hand in hand,
And with our sprightly Port make the Ghosts gaze:
Dido, and her Aeneas shall want Troops,
And all the haunt be ours. Come Eros, Eros.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: What would my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Since Cleopatra died,
I have lived in such dishonour, that the Gods
Detest my baseness. I, that with my Sword,
Quartered the World, and over green Neptunes back
With Ships, made Cities; condemn myself, to lack
The Courage of a Woman, less Noble mind
Than she which by her death, our Cæsar tells
I am Conqueror of myself. Thou art sworn Eros,
That when the exigent should come, which now
Is come indeed: When I should see behind me
The inevitable prosecution of disgrace and horror,
That on my command, thou then wouldst kill me.
Do it, the time is come: Thou strikest not me,
It is Cæsar thou defeatest. Put colour in thy Cheek.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: The Gods with-hold me,
Shall I do that which all the Parthian Darts,
(Though Enemy) lost aim, and could not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Eros,
Wouldst thou be windowed in great Rome, and see
Thy Master thus with pleached Arms, bending down
His corrigible neck, his face subdued
To penetrative shame; whilst the wheeled seat
Of Fortunate Cæsar drawn before him, branded
His Baseness that ensued.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: I would not see it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come then: for with a wound I must be cured.
Draw that thy honest Sword, which thou hast worn
Most useful for thy Country.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: O sir, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When I did make thee free, sworest thee not then
To do this when I bad thee? Do it at once,
Or thy precedent Services are all
But accidents unpurposed. Draw, and come.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Turn from me then that Noble countenance,
Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lo thee.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: My sword is drawn.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then let it do at once
The thing why thou hast drawn it.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: My dear Master,
My Captain, and my Emperor. Let me say
Before I strike this bloody stroke, Farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is said man, and farewell.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Farewell great Chief. Shall I strike now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now Eros.

sp.speaker: Eros.
sp.l: Why there then:
Thus I do escape the sorrow of Anthonies death.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thrice-Nobler than myself,
Thou teachest me: O valiant Eros, what
I should, and thou couldst not, my Queen and Eros
Have by their brave instruction got upon: me
A Nobleness in Record. But I will be
A Bridegroom in my death, and run into it
As to a Lovers bed. Come then, and Eros,
Thy Master dies thy Scholar; to do thus
I learnt of thee. How, not dead? Not dead?
The Guard, how? O dispatch me.

sp.speaker: 1.Guard.
sp.l: What is the noise?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have done my work ill Friends:
O make an end of what I have begun.
The Star is fallen.
And time is at his Period.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Alas, and woe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let him that loves me, strike me dead.
Not I.
Nor I.
Nor any one.

sp.speaker: Decretus.
sp.l: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly
This sword but shown to Cæsar with this tidings,
Shall enter me with him.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Where is Anthony?

sp.speaker: Decre.
sp.l: There Diomed there.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Lives he: wilt thou not answer man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Art thou there Diomed?
Draw thy sword, and give me,
Sufficing strokes for death.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Most absolute Lord:
My Mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: When did she send thee?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Locked in her Monument: she had a Prophesying fear
Of what hath come to pass: for when she saw
(Which never shall be found) you did suspect
She had disposed with Cæsar, and that your rage
Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead:
But fearing since how it might work, hath sent
Me to proclaim the truth, and I am come
I dread, too late.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Too late good Diomed: call my Guard I prithee.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What ho: the Emperors Guard,
The Guard, what ho? Come, your Lord calls.

div2.stage: Enter 4. or 5. of the Guard of Anthony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bear me good Friends where Cleopatra bides,
It is the last service that I shall command you.
Woe, woe are we sir, you may not live to wear
All your true Followers out.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Most heavy day.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay good my Fellows, do not please sharp fate
To grace it with your sorrows. Bid that welcome
Which comes to punish us, and we punish it
Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up:,
I have led you oft, carry me now good Friends,
And have my thanks for all.

div2.stage:
Enter Cleopatra, and her Maides aloft, with
Charmian and Iras.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Be comforted dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: No, I will not:
All strange and terrible events are welcome,
But comforts we despise; our size of sorrow
Proportioned to our cause, must be as great
As that which makes it.
How now? is he dead?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: His death is upon: him, but not dead.
Look out on the other side your Monument,
His Guard have brought him thither.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O Sun,
Burn the great Sphere thou movest in:, darkling stand
The varying shore of the world. O Antony, Antony, Antony
Help Charmian, help Iras help: help Friends
Below, let us draw him hither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace,
Not Caesar's Valour hath overthrown Anthony,
But Antony's hath Triumphed on itself.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: So it should be,
That none but Anthony should conquer Anthony,
But woe it is so:.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am dying Egypt, dying; only
I here importune death awhile, until
Of many thousand kisses, the poor last
I lay upon: thy lips.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I dare not Dear,
Dear my Lord pardon: I dare not,
Least I be taken: nor the Imperious show
Of the full-fortuned Cæsar, ever shall
Be broached with me, if Knife, Drugs, Serpents have
Edge, sting, or operation. I am safe:
Your Wife Octauia, with her modest eyes,
And still Conclusion, shall acquire no Honour
Demurring upon: me: but come, come Anthony,
Help me my women, we must draw thee up::
Assist good Friends.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O quick, or I am gone.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Here is sport indeed:
How heavy weighs my Lord?
Our strength is all gone into heaviness,
That makes the weight. Had I great Iuno's power,
The strong winged Mercury should fetch thee up:,
And set thee by Ioues side. Yet come a little,
Wishers were ever Fools. O come, come, come,
sp.stage: They heaue Anthony aloft to Cleopatra.
sp.l: And welcome, welcome. Die when thou hast lived,
Quicken with kissing: had my lips that power,
Thus would I wear them out.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A heavy sight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am dying Egypt, dying.
Give me some Wine, and let me speak a little.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: No, let me speak, and let me rail so high,
That the false Housewife Fortune, break her Wheel,
Provoked by my offence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: One word (sweet Queen)
Of Cæsar seek your Honour, with your safety. O.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: They do not go together.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Gentle hear me,
None about Cæsar trust, but Proculeius.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: My Resolution, and my hands, I will trust,
None about Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The miserable change now at my end,
Lament nor sorrow at: but please your thoughts
In feeding them with those my former Fortunes
Wherein I lived. The greatest Prince of the world,
The Noblest: and do now not basely die,
Not Cowardly put off my Helmet to
My Countryman. A Roman, by a Roman
Valiantly vanquished. Now my Spirit is going,
I can no more.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Noblest of men, wilt die?
Hast thou no care of me, shall I abide
In this dull world, which in thy absence is
No better than a Sty? O see my women:
The Crown of the earth doth melt. My Lord?
O withered is the Garland of the War,
The Soldiers pole is fallen: young Boys and Girls
Are level now with men: The odds is gone,
And there is nothing left remarkable
Beneath the visiting Moon.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O quietness, Lady.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: She is dead too, our Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O Madam, Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Royal Egypt: Empress.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Peace, peace, Iras.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: No more but in a Woman, and commanded
By such poor passion, as the Maid that Milks,
And does the meanest chars. It were for me,
To throw my Sceptre at the injurious Gods,
To tell them that this World did equal theirs
Till they had stolen our Jewel. All is but naught:
Patience is sortish, and impatience does
Become a Dog that is mad: Then is it sin,
To rush into the secret house of death,
Ere death dare come to us. How do you Women?
What, what good cheer? Why how now Charmian?
My Noble Girls? Ah Women, women! Look
Our Lamp is spent, it is out. Good sirs, take heart,
We will bury him: And then, what is brave, what is Noble,
Let us do it after the high Roman fashion,
And make death proud to take us. Come, away,
This case of that huge Spirit now is cold.
Ah Women, Women! Come, we have no Friend
But Resolution, and the briefest end.

div2.stage:
Enter Cæsar, Agrippa, Dollabella, Menas, with
Counsell of Warre.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Go to him Dollabella, bid him yield,
Being so frustrate, tell him,
He mocks the pauses that he makes.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Cæsar, I shall.

div2.stage: Enter Decretas with the sword of Anthony.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Wherefore is that? And what art thou that darest
Appear thus to us?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I am called Decretas,
Marke Anthony I served, who best was worthy
Best to be served: whilst he stood up:, and spoke
He was my Master, and I wore my life
To spend upon: his haters. If thou please
To take me to thee, as I was to him,
I will be to Cæsar: if thou pleasest not, I yield thee up my life.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: What is it thou sayst?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I say (O Cæsar) Anthony is dead.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: The breaking of so great a thing, should make
A greater crack. The round World
Should have shook Lions into civil streets,
And Citizens to their dens. The death of Anthony
Is not a single doom, in the name lay
A moiety of the world.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: He is dead Cæsar,
Not by a public minister of Justice,
Nor by a hired Knife, but that self-hand
Which writ his Honour in the Acts it did,
Hath with the Courage which the heart did lend it,
Splitted the heart. This is his Sword,
I robbed his wound of it: behold it stained
With his most Noble blood.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Look you sad Friends,
The Gods rebuke me, but it is Tidings
To wash the eyes of Kings.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: And strange it is,
That Nature must compel us to lament
Our most persisted deeds.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: His taints and Honours, waged equal with him.

sp.speaker: Dola.
sp.l: A Rarer spirit never
Did steer humanity: but you Gods will give us
Some faults to make us men. Cæsar is touched.

sp.speaker: Mec.
sp.l: When such a spacious Mirror is set before him,
He needs must see himself.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: O Anthony,
I have followed thee to this, but we do launch
Diseases in our Bodies. I must perforce
Have shown to thee such a declining day,
Or look on thine: we could not stall together,
In the whole world. But yet let me lament
With tears as Sovereign as the blood of hearts,
That thou my Brother, my Competitor,
In top of all design; my Mate in Empire,
Friend and Companion in the front of War,
The Arm of mine own Body, and the Heart
Where mine his thoughts did kindle; that our Stars
Unreconciliable, should divide our equalness to this.
Hear me good Friends,
But I will tell you at some meeter Season,
The business of this man looks out of him,
We will hear him what he says.
Whence are you?

sp.speaker: Aegyp.
sp.l: A poor Egyptian yet, the Queen my mistress
Confined in all, she has her Monument
Of thy intents, desires, instruction,
That she preparedly may frame herself
To the way she is forced to:.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Bid her have good heart,
She soon shall know of us, by some of ours,
How honourable, and how kindly Werp:
Determine for her. For Cæsar cannot leave to be ungentle

sp.speaker: Aegypt.
sp.l: So the Gods preserve thee.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Come hither Proculeius. Go and say
We purpose her no shame: give her what comforts
The quality of her passion shall require;
Least in her greatness, by some mortal stroke
She do defeat us. For her life in Rome,
Would be eternal in our Triumph: Go,
And with your speediest bring us what she says,
And how you find of her.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Cæsar I shall.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Gallus, go you along: where is Dolabella, to second Proculeius?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Dolabella.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Let him alone: for I remember now
How he is employed: he shall in time be ready.
Go with me to my Tent, where you shall see
How hardly I was drawn into this War,
How calm and gentle I proceeded still
In all my Writings. Go with me, and see
What I can show in this.

div2.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Mardian.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: My desolation does begin to make
A better life: It is paltry to be Cæsar:
Not being Fortune, he is but Fortunes knave,
A minister of her will: and it is great
To do that thing that ends all other deeds,
Which shackles accedence, and bolts up change;
Which sleeps, and never palates more the dung,
The beggars Nurse, and Cæsars.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Cæsar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt,
And bids thee study on what fair demands
Thou meanest to have him grant thee.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My name is Proculeius.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Did tell me of you, bad me trust you, but
I do not greatly care to be deceived
That have no use for trusting. If your Master
Would have a Queen his beggar, you must tell him,
That Majesty to keep decorum, must
No less beg than a Kingdom: If he please
To give me conquered Egypt for my Son,
He gives me so much of mine own, as I
Will kneel to him with thanks.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Be of good cheer:
You are fallen into a Princely hand, fear nothing,
Make your full reference freely to my Lord,
Who is so full of Grace, that it flows over
On all that need. Let me report to him
Your sweet dependency, and you shall find
A Conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness,
Where he for grace is kneeled to:.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Pray you tell him,
I am his Fortunes Vassal, and I send him
The Greatness he has got. I hourly learn
A Doctrine of Obedience, and would gladly
Look him in the Face.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: This I will report (dear Lady)
Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitied
Of him that caused it.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You see how easily she may be surprised:
Guard her till Cæsar come.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Royal Queen.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O Cleopatra, thou art taken Queen.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Quick, quick, good hands.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Hold worthy Lady, hold:
do not yourself such wrong, who are in this
Relieved, but not betrayed.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What of death too that rids our dogs of languish

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Cleopatra, do not abuse my Masters bounty, by
The undoing of
yourself: Let the World see
His Nobleness well acted, which your death
Will never let come forth.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Where art thou Death?
Come hither come; Come, come, and take a Queen
Worth many Babes and Beggars.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O temperance Lady.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sir, I will eat no meate, I will not drink sir,
If idle talk will once be necessary
I will not sleep neither. This mortal house I will ruin,
Do Cæsar what he can. Know sir, that I
Will not wait pinioned at your Masters Court,
Nor once be chastised with the sober eye
Of dull Octauia. Shall they hoist me up,
And show me to the shouting Varlotarie
Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt.
Be gentle grave unto me, rather on Nylus mud
Lay me stark-naked, and let the water-Flies
Blow me into abhorring; rather make
My Countries high pyramids my Gibbet,
And hang me up: in Chains.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You do extend
These thoughts of horror further than you shall
Find cause in Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Proculeius, What thou hast done, thy Master Cæsar knows,
And he hath sent for thee: for the Queen,
I will take her to my Guard.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: So Dolabella,
It shall content me best: Be gentle to her,
To Cæsar I will speak, what you shall please,
If you will: employ me to him.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Say, I would die.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Most Noble Empress, you have heard of me.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Assuredly you know me.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: No matter sir, what I have heard or known:
You laugh when Boys or Women tell their Dreams,
Is it not your trick?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: I understand not, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I dreamt there was an Emperor Anthony.
O such another sleep, that I might see
But such another man.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: If it might please ye.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: His face was as the Heavens, and therein stuck
A Sun and Moon, which kept their course, and lighted
The little of the earth.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Most Sovereign Creature.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: His legs bestrode the Ocean, his reared arm
Crested the world: His voice was propertied
As all the tuned Spheres, and that to Friends:
But when he meant to quail, and shake the Orb,
He was as rattling Thunder. For his Bounty,
There was no winter in it. An Anthony it was,
That grew the more by reaping: His delights
Were Dolphin-like, they showed his back above
The Element they lived in: In his Livery
Crowns and Coronets: Realms and Islands were
As plates dropped from his pocket.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Think you there was, or might be such a man
As this I dreamt of?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Gentle Madam, no.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: You Lie up: to the hearing of the Gods:
But if there be, not ever were one such
It is past the size of dreaming: Nature wants stuff
To vie strange forms with fancy, yet to imagine
An Anthony were Natures piece, against Fancy,
Condemning shadows quite.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Hear me, good Madam:
Your loss is as yourself, great; and you bear it
As answering to the weight, would I might never
Overtake pursued success: But I do feel
By the rebound of yours, a grief that suites
My very heart at root.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: I thank you sir:
Know you what Cæsar means to do with me?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: I am loath to tell you what, I would you knew.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Nay pray you sir.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Though he be Honourable.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He will lead me then in Triumph.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Madam he will:, I know it.

div2.stage:
Enter Proculeius, Cæsar, Gallus, Mecenas,
and others of his Traine.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Make way there Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cæs.
sp.l: Which is the Queen of Egypt.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: It is the Emperor Madam.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Arise, you shall not kneel:
I pray you rise, rise Egypt.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sir,the Gods will have it thus,
My Master and my Lord I must obey,

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Take to you no hard thoughts,
The Record of what injuries you did us,
Though written in our flesh, we shall remember
As things but done by chance.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Sole Sir of the World,
I cannot project mine own cause so well
To make it clear, but do confess I have
Been laden with like frailties, which before
Have often shamed our Sex.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Cleopatra know,
We will extenuate rather than enforce:
If you apply yourself to our intents,
Which towards you are most gentle, you shall find
A benefit in this change: but if you seek
To lay on me a Cruelty, by taking
Anthonies course, you shall bereave yourself
Of my good purposes, and put your children
To that destruction which I will guard them from,
If thereon you rely. I will take my leave.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: And may through all the world: it is yours, and we
your Scutcheons, and your signs of Conquest shall
Hang in what place you please. Here my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: This is the brief: of Money, Plate, and Jewels
I am possessed of, it is exactly valued,
Not petty things admitted. where is Seleucus?

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.l: Here Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: This is my Treasurer, let him speak (my Lord)
Upon: his peril, that I have reserved
To myself nothing. Speak the truth Seleucus.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.l: Madam, I had rather seal my lips,
Than to my peril speak that which is not.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: What have I kept back.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Enough to purchase what you have made known

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Nay blush not Cleopatra, I approve
Your Wisdom in the deed.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: See Cæsar:
O behold,
How pomp is followed: Mine will now be yours,
And should we shift estates, yours would be mine.
The ingratitude of this Seleucus, does
Even make me wild. O Slave, of no more trust
Than love that is hired? What goest thou back, thou shalt
Go back I warrant thee: but I will catch thine eyes
Though they had wings. Slave, Soulless, Villain, Dog.
O rarely base!

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Good Queen, let us entreat you.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O Cæsar, what a wounding shame is this,
That thou vouchsafing here to visit me,
Doing the Honour of thy Lordliness
To one so meek, that mine own Servant should
Parcel the sum of my disgraces, by
Addition of his Envy. Say (good Cæsar)
That I some Lady trifles have reserved,
Immoment toys, things of such Dignity
As we greet modern Friends withal, and say
Some Nobler token I have kept apart
For Liuia and Octauia, to induce
Their mediation, must I be unfolded
With one that I have bred: The Gods! it smites me
Beneath the fall I have. Prithee go hence,
Or I shall show the Cinders of my spirits
Through the Ashes of my chance: Wert thou a man,
Thou wouldst have mercy on me.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Forbear Seleucus.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Be it known, that we the greatest are misthought
For things that others do: and when we fall,
We answer others merits, in our name
Are therefore to be pitied.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Cleopatra,
Not what you have reserved, nor what acknowledged
Put we in the Roll of Conquest: still be it yours,
Bestow it at your pleasure, and believe
Cæsars no Merchant, to make prize with you
Of things that Merchants sold. Therefore be cheered,
Make not your thoughts your prisons: No dear Queen,
For we intend so to dispose you, as
Yourself shall give us counsel: Feed, and sleep:
Our care and pity is so much upon: you,
That we remain your Friend, and so adieu.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: My Master, and my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Not so:: Adieu.

div2.stage: Flourish. Exeunt Cæsar, and his Traine.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: He words me Girls, he words me,
That I should not be Noble to myself.
But hark thee Charmian.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Finish good Lady, the bright day is done,
And we are for the dark.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Hie thee again,
I have spoke already, and it is provided,
Go put it to the haste.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Madam, I will:.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: where is the Queen?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Behold sir.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Dolabella.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Madam, as thereto sworn, by your command
(Which my love makes Religion to obey)
I tell you this: Cæsar through Syria
Intends his journey, and within three days,
You with your Children will he send before,
Make your best use of this. I have performed
Your pleasure, and my promise.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Dolabella, I shall remain your debtor.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: I your Servant:
Adieu good Queen, I must attend on Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Farewell, and thanks.
Now Iras, what thinkst thou?
Thou, an Egyptian Puppet shall be shown
In Rome as well as I: Mechanic Slaves
With greasy Aprons, Rules, and Hammers shall
Uplift us to the view. In their thick breathes,
Rank of gross diet, shall we be enclouded,
And forced to drink their vapour.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: The Gods forbid.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Nay, it is most certain Iras: saucy Lictors
Will catch at us like Strumpets, and scald Rhymers
Ballads us out of Tune. The quick Comedians
Extemporally will stage us, and present
Our Alexandrian Revels: Anthony
Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see
Some squeaking Cleopatra Boy my greatness
In the posture of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: O the good Gods!

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Nay that is certain.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: I will never see it? for I am sure mine Nails
Are stronger than mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Why that is the way to fool their preparation,
And to conquer their most absurd intents.
Now Charmian.
Show me my Women like a Queen: Go fetch
My best Attires. I am again for Cidrus,
To meet Marke Anthony. Sirrah Iras, go
(Now Noble Charmian, we will: dispatch indeed,)
And when thou hast done this char, I will give thee leave
To play till Doomsday: bring our Crown, and all.
Wherefore is this noise?

sp.speaker: Gards.
sp.l: Here is a rural Fellow,
That will not be denied your Highness presence,
He brings you Figs.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Let him come in:.
What poor an Instrument
May do a Noble deed: he brings me liberty:
My Resolution is placed, and I have nothing
Of woman in me: Now from head to foot
I am Marble constant: now the fleeting Moon
No Planet is of mine.

sp.speaker: Guards.
sp.l: This is the man.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Avoid, and leave him.
Hast thou the pretty worm of Nylus there,
That kills and pains not?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Truly I have him: but I would not be the party
that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is
immortal: those that do die of it, do seldom or never
recover.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Rememberest thou any that have died of it?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Very many, men and women too. I heard of
one of them no longer than yesterday, a very honest woman,
but something given to lie, as a woman should not
do, but in the way of honesty, how she died of the biting
of it, what pain she felt: Truly, she makes a very
good report of the worm: but he that will: believe all that
they say, shall never be saved by half that they do: but
this is most fallible, the Worm is an odd Worm.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Get thee hence, farewell.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I wish you all joy of the Worm.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
You must think this (look you,) that the
Worm will do his kind.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Aye, aye, farewell.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Look you, the Worm is not to be trusted,
but in the keeping of wise people: for indeed, there is
no goodness in the Worm.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Take thou no care, it shall be heeded.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Very good: give it nothing I pray you, for it
is not worth the feeding.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Will it eat me?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
You must not think I am so simple, but I know
the devil himself will not eat a woman: I know, that
a woman is a dish for the Gods, if the devil dress her
not. But truly, these same whoreson devils do the Gods
great harm in their women: for in every ten that they
make, the devils mar five.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.p: Well, get thee gone, farewell.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Yes forsooth: I wish you joy of the worm.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Give me my Robe, put on my Crown, I have
Immortal longings in me. Now no more
The juice of Egypts Grape shall moist this lip.
Yare, yare, good Iras; quick: Methinks I hear
Anthony call: I see him rouse himself
To praise my Noble Act. I hear him mock
The luck of Cæsar, which the Gods give men
To excuse their after wrath. Husband, I come:
Now to that name, my Courage prove my Title.
I am Fire, and Air; my other Elements
I give to baser life. So:, have you done?
Come then, and take the last warmth of my Lips.
Farewell kind Charmian, Iras, long farewell.
Have I the Aspic in my lips? Dost fall?
If thou, and Nature can so gently part,
The stroke of death is as a Lovers pinch,
Which hurts, and is desired. Dost thou lie still?
If thus thou vanishest, thou tellest the world,
It is not worth leave-taking.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Dissolve thick cloud, and Rain, that I may say
The Gods themselves do weep.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: This proves me base:
If she first meet the Curled Anthony,
He will make demand of her, and spend that kiss
Which is my heaven to have. Come thou mortal wretch,
With thy sharpe teeth this knot intricate,
Of life at once untie: Poor venomous Fool,
Be angry, and dispatch. O couldst thou speak
That I might hear thee call great Cæsar Ass, unpolicied.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O Eastern Star.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Peace, peace:
Dost thou not see my Baby at my breast,
That sucks the Nurse asleep.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O break! O break!

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: As sweet as Balm, as soft as Air, as gentle.
O Anthony! Nay I will take thee too.
What should I stay -;

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: In this wild World? So fare thee well:
Now boast thee Death, in thy possession lies
A Lass unparalleled. Downy Windows close,
And golden Phoebus, never be beheld
Of eyes again so Royal: your Crowns away,
I will mend it, and then play -;

div2.stage: Enter the Guard rustling in: and Dolabella.

sp.speaker: 1.Guard.
sp.l: where is the Queen?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Speak softly, wake her not.
Cæsar hath sent

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Too slow a Messenger.
O come apace, dispatch, I partly feel thee.
Approach ho,
All is not well: Caesar is beguiled.
There is Dolabella sent from Cæsar: call him.
What work is here Charmian?
Is this well done?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: It is well done, and fitting for a Princess
Descended of so many Royal Kings.
Ah Soldier.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: How goes it here?

sp.speaker: 2.Guard.
sp.l: All dead.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Cæsar, thy thoughts
Touch their effects in this: Thyself art coming
To see performed the dreaded Act which thou
So soughtest to hinder.

div2.stage: Enter Cæsar and all his Train, marching.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A way there, a way for Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: O sir, you are too sure an Augurer:
That you did fear, is done.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Bravest at the last,
She leveled at our purposes, and being Royal
Took her own way: the manner of their deaths,
I do not see them bleed.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Who was last with them?

sp.speaker: 1.Guard.
sp.l: A simple Countryman, that brought her Figs:
This was his Basket.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Poisoned then.

sp.speaker: 1.Guard.
sp.l: O Cæsar:
This Charmian lived but now, she stood and spake:
I found her trimming up: the Diadem;
On her dead Mistress tremblingly she stood,
And on the sudden dropped.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: O Noble weakness:
If they had swallowed poison, it would appear
By external swelling: but she looks like sleep,
As she would catch another Anthony
In her strong toil of Grace.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Here on her breast,
There is a vent of Blood, and something blown,
The like is on her Arm.

sp.speaker: 1.Guard.
sp.l: This is an Aspic's trail,
And these Fig-leaves have slime upon them, such
As the Aspic leaves upon the Caves of Nyle.

sp.speaker: Cæsar.
sp.l: Most probable
That so she died: for her Physician tells me
She hath pursued Conclusions infinite
Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed,
And bear her Women from the Monument,
She shall be buried by her Anthony.
No Grave upon: the earth shall clip in it
A pair so famous: high events as these
Strike those that make them: and their Story is
No less in pity, than his Glory which
Brought them to be lamented. Our Army shall
In solemn show, attend this Funeral,
And then to Rome. Come Dolabella, see
High Order, in this great Solemnity.
